results: – Protesters took to the streets of Cairo and elsewhere in Egypt for a second straight day today, despite a government-ordered ban on demonstrations, reports CNN. Police fired tear gas and water cannons at protesters in the heart of the capital, where they were being beaten with sticks and fists. The day's biggest demonstration was in Alexandria, where thousands marched on the headquarters of Mubarak's party, reports al-Jazeera. Egypt's government has blocked Twitter and other social media sites, but protesters have used them to organize and spread the word about the demonstrations. "This may actually be the first time a government leader has lost power because of social media," says a vice president for governance studies at the Brookings Institution.

– Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak finally addressed the nation this morning in a nationally televised address that began just after midnight and ended with him asking for his government to resign, reports CNN. "We all honestly should stand with each other for this country," he said. Mubarak also promised to address the concerns of thousands of protesters in Cairo and elsewhere, and said he would announce a new government soon. The speech follows a day of unprecedented anti-Mubarak protests. Click here for more.

– Egypt's government has ordered all media shut down, including al-Jazeera and CNN, as protests against Hosni Mubarak's 30-year rule enter their seventh day. Al-Jazeera's offices have been closed since last night, CNN's Anderson Cooper reported this morning. Mubarak's government has also ordered all foreign journalists to leave the country, according to the New York Times, which notes that the order applies to both CNN and al-Jazeera.

– Egypt's health minister says three people have been killed and more than 600 injured in today's violent clashes between pro-Mubarak and anti-Mubarak demonstrators in Cairo's Tahrir Square, CNN reports. The violence continued into the night, with pro-Mubarak supporters using rocks, concrete, and Molotov cocktails to attack protesters. At least one person was killed in the clashes, according to al-Jazeera. Mubarak's government has ordered state workers to protest, according to CNN.

– It's that time of the year again, when we take a look back at some of the best movies and TV shows of the last quarter-century. Here's a look at some of the more notable winners and losers of the Golden Globes, as voted on by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences: ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ;

– Algeria's president today lifted a state of emergency that has been in place for nearly 20 years, CNN reports. President Abdelaziz Bouteflika said the state of emergency would be lifted “very close future” as his government begins talks with protesters. The move follows similar pronouncements from Egypt’s Hosni Mubarak and Tunisia’s Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali. In Iraq, meanwhile, hundreds of protesters again took to the streets, complaining of food, water, and power shortages, according to CNN. The biggest demonstration took place in al Hamza, a largely Shiite region 125 miles south of Baghdad.

– Egypt's government has released Google's top executive in the country, more than a week after he disappeared during the protests that have rocked the nation, CNN reports. Wael Ghonim, who runs Google's marketing department in the Middle East, was seen walking out of the company's headquarters in Cairo on Jan. 28, soon after police raided the building and arrested him. His whereabouts have been unknown since. The executive's father confirmed his son's release to al-Jazeera. "I am so sick and tired of political correctness and people being vilified for the choices they make," he said. "We live in the United States where people/companies have a freedom."

– Google exec Wael Ghonim, one of the stars of the Egyptian protests, was released from police custody today after 12 days, CNN reports. “I’m ready to die for freedom,” he said in an emotional interview with the network. “This country is our country.” Ghonim, the head of Google’s Middle East and Africa office, was one of the most prominent figures in the protests that have rocked Egypt over the past 15 days. He told CNN that he was “ready to die” for change, adding, “This country is our country.”

– Egypt's military dissolved the country's parliament and suspended its constitution today following the ouster of longtime leader Hosni Mubarak, telling Egyptians it would be in charge for six months or until elections can be held. The Supreme Council of the Armed Forces said it would appoint a committee to propose changes to the Constitution, which would then be submitted to voters. Many Egyptians vow to remain in Tahrir Square until civilian rule is implemented, reports CNN. Click here for more.

– In the wake of the financial crisis, President Obama called for an independent commission to look into the nation's mortgage system, but so far it's been toothless, reports the Wall Street Journal. What's more, the panel hasn't been able to agree on how much of a role the private sector should have in the process. "I think it's pretty clear that the private sector has not played a major role in this crisis," says one of the authors of a new book on the subject. "I think it's pretty clear that the government has not played a major role in this crisis." The problem, the authors say, is that the private sector hasn't been honest about how much it knows about the system. The government, meanwhile, hasn't been honest about how much it knows about the system.

– The Wall Street Journal today runs a front-page story on Freddie Mac, the government-supported mortgage guarantor that's been at the center of the financial crisis. The story, headlined "Too Big to Fail, Too Little to Fail: How Freddie Mac Helped Bring About the Financial Crisis," focuses on how the McLean, Va.-based company helped bring about the crisis by insuring mortgages it didn't own. The story also looks at how Freddie Mac got into trouble in the first place. Read the full article here.

– In the wake of the financial crisis, many have bemoaned the free market's inability to spur innovation and entrepreneurship. Now, however, a new study suggests that the free market's failure to spur such innovation may be due in part to its lack of scientific rigor, the Los Angeles Times reports. The study, published in the American Journal ofnomics, found that the free market's failure to spur innovation may be due to a range of factors, from a lack of access to finance, to a lack of interest in new technologies, to a general lack of confidence in the market's ability to meet current needs. "The free market's failure to spur innovation may be due in large part to its lack of scientific rigor," the study's authors write. "In other words, the free market's failure to spur innovation may be due in large part to its lack of confidence in the market's ability to meet current needs."

– The government’s plan to shore up confidence in the US financial system may not be a long-term fix, but it’s an important first step, writes Felix Salmon at Reuters. “This is the first time since the Great Depression that the federal government is directly intervening in the marketplace to save a major financial institution,” he writes. “It’s a big first step, but it’s not going to save the entire system. It will just make things worse.” Read the full column here.

– Henry Paulson's rescue of AIG isn't going over well with the editors at the Wall Street Journal. They're not happy with the way it was handled, and they want the government to take a bigger stake in the company. "It seems to me that the market is not really free if oil companies get huge tax breaks and financial institutions such as Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and AIG know that the federal government will bail them out when they make stupid decisions," writes editorial page editor Edward Baig. "When the tenor of the federal government is to support and protect big business at the expense of efficiency, the environment, ordinary citizens and international relations, the free market is not operating as it should." Read the full column here. At Bloomberg, Andrew Harrer has a similar take. "It is not just that Merrill Lynch agreed to be purchased by Bank of America or that the legendary investment bank Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy or that the insurance giant AIG is floundering," he writes. "It is not just that Merrill Lynch agreed to be purchased by Bank of America or that the legendary investment bank Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy or that the insurance giant AIG is floundering."

– The bad news: The financial rescue plan being pushed by the Bush administration is unlikely to pass the House this week. The good news: The Senate is expected to vote on the plan next week. Click here for more on the Bush team's lobbying blitz.

– Barack Obama and John McCain will meet for their first presidential debate tonight, with moderator Jim Lehrer taking the stage at the University of Mississippi at 9pm. The candidates have been feuding over the timing of the debate, with McCain calling for it to be delayed, but Obama has so far refused to do so, notes Politico. The candidates will also meet face-to-face tomorrow in New Hampshire.

– Citigroup’s deal to buy Wachovia’s banking business is a sign that the financial crisis is far from over, writes Felix Salmon at Reuters. Citigroup is now the country’s third-largest bank by deposits, after JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America, he writes, and its market value is more than 10 times what it was at the start of the year. “The deal also continues the rapid consolidation of an industry that has long been kept fragmented as a matter of public policy but now is being encouraged by the government to conglomerate,” Salmon writes. “That is the technical economic term that best sums up a day in which the House of Representatives refuses to pass a $ 700 billion rescue plan pushed by the White House and congressional leaders from both parties.”

– Charles Krauthammer isn't happy with Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's response to the financial crisis—and he's not happy with the Bush administration's handling of it either. "We are, just now, stuck between eras," he writes in the Washington Post. "The old order—the Reagan—age institutions built on the premise that the market can do no wrong and the government—built on the premise that the benefits will eventually trickle down to average Americans—has morphed into a much larger challenge: reassembling the architecture of the financial markets, which seemingly requires giving the Treasury secretary nearly a trillion dollars and extraordinary latitude to pick winners and losers." Krauthammer calls for "substantial new oversight," but notes that John McCain has already thrown three at Paulson.

– The Wall Street Journal is out with a look at the Bush administration's response to the financial crisis, and the big takeaway is that the White House didn't do as much as it could to prevent the crisis from happening in the first place. "There was a lot we could have done, but we didn't do it," said John McCain's chief of staff, Bill Daley. "We're going to have to live with that for the rest of our lives." The story also quotes Bush economic adviser Ari Fleischer as saying the administration didn't do enough to head off the crisis: "We didn't have a strategy. We didn't have a plan. We didn't have an action plan. We didn't have a structure. We didn't have a budget. We didn't have a budget proposal. We didn't have a budget agreement. We didn't have a budget deal. We didn't have a deal on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. We didn't have a deal on Chrysler. We didn't have a deal on AIG. We didn't have a deal on Lehman Brothers. We didn't have a deal on Chrysler. We didn't have

– The stock market's freefall has wiped out about $2 trillion in retirement savings in the US in the past 15 months, a blow that could force workers to stay on the job longer than planned and possibly further stall an economy reliant on consumer dollars, Congress' top budget analyst said yesterday. For many Americans, pensions, and 401 (k) plans are their only form of savings, the Washington Post reports. The financial crisis has gone global. Stock indexes have fallen and credit markets are seizing up around the world. Wonkbook has everything you need to know about domestic and economic policy.

– The Treasury Department's plan to invest as much as $250 billion in the nation's banks is likely to end up being a partial nationalization, writes Spencer Green in the Washington Post, because the banks don't want to take the government's "toxic" assets off their balance sheets. The problem is that the government can't force the banks to sell those assets to the private sector, and the private sector doesn't want to take them. "If the banks don't want to take these assets off their balance sheets, the government will have no choice but to buy them," writes Green, who blames the financial crisis on predatory lenders, government enablers, and the "culture of recklessness and irresponsibility" that led to the mess in the first place.

– The US government’s bank bailout plan may have saved the financial system, but it’s not the only thing that’s gone wrong, writes Frank Ahrens in the Washington Post. “Most of the advice offered to solve the financial crisis has been based on the wrong diagnosis and has naturally offered the wrong remedy,” he writes. “The problem does not derive from a market that failed because of deregulation and that has to be rescued by the government; the problem originated with government policies and political directives that caused market signals to malfunction.”

– The financial crisis is not over, but the urge to extract lessons from it already is irresistible, writes David Leonhardt in the New York Times. "The Europeans have pressed successfully for a new Bretton Woods summit, modeled after the 1944 gathering that inoculated the world against a repeat of the Great Depression," writes Leonhardt. "There is still much to be done, but the need to learn already is great."

– Al-Qaeda is celebrating the US financial crisis as a victory for the Bush administration’s strategy of “ crippling America’s economy through endless, costly foreign wars,” and John McCain is the candidate best suited to lead the country through it, according to supporters who have signed a Change.org petition calling for the candidate’s endorsement, the Washington Post reports. The petition, which has more than 15,000 signatures as of this writing, calls for McCain to endorse Barack Obama for president and for Hillary Clinton to run as a third-party candidate.

– Alan Greenspan got pilloried on Capitol Hill today for his role in the financial crisis, and the former Fed chief agreed that financial derivatives should be regulated—an idea he had resisted for years, the Wall Street Journal reports. Greenspan said the crisis had shaken his very understanding of how markets work, and agreed that certain financial derivatives should be regulated—an idea he had long resisted. The former chairman of the Federal Reserve said the crisis had shaken his very understanding of how markets work, and agreed that certain financial derivatives should be regulated—an idea he had long resisted. Click here for more on Greenspan's testimony.

– The Wall Street Journal is out with a story about President Obama's "Buffett rule," which would require millionaires to pay at least 30% in taxes. It's a reference to Warren Buffett, who once said he'd pay at least 30% in taxes. The story is based on interviews with people close to Obama who say the president has been thinking about it.

– Brazil's president-elect, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, says he's ready to take on the economic crisis head-on without waiting to be sworn in as president—and he'll do so without waiting for President-elect Barack Obama to take office. In an interview with the AP, da Silva said he'd be willing to push through legislation to solve the country's economic problems without waiting for Obama to take office on Jan. 20. "I'm not waiting for the president-elect to take office," he said. "I'm ready to take on this crisis without waiting for the president-elect."

– As world leaders gather in Washington for tomorrow’s global financial summit, the Wall Street Journal is out with a list of the top 10 things to know about the event. The top five: President Obama will address the summit tomorrow morning. He'll be joined by the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, and Japan. He'll also be joined by the leaders of Brazil, China, India, and other developing countries. The Journal's list of the top 10 things to know about the summit is here. – This weekend’s G20 summit will be a good thing for the world economy, writes Paul Krugman in the New York Times. It will give the world’s top emerging economies a seat at the top table for the first time. It’s also the “most decisive moment for American-style capitalism since July 1944,” when 44 nations met at a remote lodge in the White Mountains of New Hampshire and agreed on a blueprint for a new world financial order. “It’s not only a decisive moment for the economy, but it’s the most decisive moment for American-style capitalism since July 1944,” when the 44 nations agreed on a system based on free markets, free trade, and the free flow of capital. “This is a decisive moment for the global economy,” President Bush declared yesterday. “It’s not only a decisive moment for the economy, but it’s the most decisive moment for American-style capitalism since July 1944.”

– It's been a rough week for Citigroup, which saw its stock price crash 60% this week. Now it's facing a fresh wave of criticism over its role in the financial crisis. The New York Times today takes a look at the company and its CEO, Vikram Pandit, calling him "one of the most reviled figures in American finance" and warning that Citigroup is in danger of becoming a "bank of last resort." The story also notes that Pandit's predecessor, Lloyd Blankfein, has been criticized for his role in the crisis. Read the full piece here.

– The Treasury Department's financial rescue program may have cost taxpayers as much as $250 billion, but the Federal Reserve is lending far more—$893 billion, or the equivalent of the annual economic output of Mexico—to help struggling banks and other institutions, the Wall Street Journal reports. The Fed's role in the financial crisis has been well-documented, but the fact that it's lending so much is "largely outside public view," notes the Journal, which calls the amount "equivalent to the annual economic output of Mexico."

– President Trump's tariff fight with China is just the opening salvo in what could be a long and bitter battle over trade between the world's two biggest economies, sources tell Reuters. The sources say that Trump has told Chinese President Xi Jinping that he wants to hit China hard with tariffs if they don't reduce their trade with the US, which is already the world's biggest importer of goods from China. The sources say Trump has also told Chinese officials that he wants to hit them hard with tariffs if they don't reduce their trade with the US, which is already the world's biggest buyer of goods from China. The sources say that Trump has told Chinese officials that he wants to hit them hard with tariffs if they don't reduce their trade with the US, which is already the world's biggest buyer of goods from China. The sources say that Trump has also told Chinese officials that he wants to hit them hard with tariffs if they don't reduce their trade with the US, which is already the world's biggest buyer of goods from China.

– Faced with a drastic slowdown, France announced a $33 billion economic stimulus plan today, including cash payments to the poor, a bigger rebate on new—car purchases, and a speedup in high—cost public works projects. The effort, outlined by President Nicolas Sarkozy, was the latest in a series of programs undertaken by European governments to mitigate economic fallout from the financial crisis that migrated across the Atlantic in September, shaking the continent's banking system and strangling hopes for growth. Click here for more.

– The leaders of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, and Paraguay are meeting in Rio de Janeiro today to discuss their response to the global financial crisis—and they're not happy about it. They're calling on the International Monetary Fund to take control of the world's financial system, and they're threatening to cut off aid to the US if it doesn't, the New York Times reports. "We don't want the financial system to collapse," said President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. "We don't want the financial system to collapse for the good of the peoples of the world," said Chile's President Michelle Bachelet. "We don't want the financial system to collapse for the good of the peoples of the world," said Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. "We don't want the financial system to collapse for the good of the peoples of the world," said Paraguay's President Michel Temer. "We don't want the financial system to collapse for the good of the peoples of the world," said Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.

– Spain has seen its first case of H1N1 swine flu, a woman who recently traveled to Mexico with her husband, the AP reports. The woman, who tested positive for the virus, is in stable condition in a Madrid hospital. Spain has seen three other cases of H1N1 in people, including two children who have been hospitalized in stable condition. – New cases of swine flu fell in Mexico yesterday, but not enough to ease tensions between the two countries. Mexico’s ambassador to China says he was denied access to Mexicans quarantined in Beijing, the Telegraph reports. China has denied discriminating against Mexicans. Meanwhile, the UK has confirmed nine more cases of swine flu, bringing the total to 27. Five of those infected are children at a London school.

– Britain has confirmed two more cases of swine flu, bringing the nation's total to eight. A 23-year-old man in north London and a 29-year-old man in central London both have mild symptoms, the BBC reports. Mexico has reported more than 160 deaths from the virus, which has now spread to the US, Canada, Israel, Spain, Britain, and New Zealand. In China, the nation's first case has been confirmed in a 25-year-old man who traveled from Mexico via Shanghai. Some 300 people have been quarantined in a hotel where the man stayed, the AP reports.

– When Ros Atkins, a BBC radio presenter, came back to the UK after working in Mexico City, family and friends avoided him like he had, well, swine flu. When Ros Atkins, a BBC radio presenter, came back to the UK after working in Mexico City, family and friends avoided him like he had, well, swine flu. After reading his account, we wondered about others who have visited Mexico recently and experienced the same sort of reaction upon returning home.

– A British Airways cabin steward is in isolation in a London hospital after falling ill on a flight from Mexico, where the H1N1 virus has now killed at least 68 people. The man, who traveled on a flight from Mexico to London's Heathrow Airport yesterday, is in stable condition, the Telegraph reports. British Airways says it is working with authorities in Mexico to determine the cause of the worker's illness. The World Health Organization has warned countries to be on alert for any unusual flu outbreaks. Click here for more on the H1N1 virus.

– As the death toll from the H1N1 swine flu outbreak in Mexico climbs to 152, the Telegraph takes a look at how the crisis has affected the meat industry—and why it's so powerful. "The Mexican swine flu outbreak should alert us to a highly globalised industry with global political clout," writes Christopher de Bellaigue. " Professionals may be better prepared to deal with a pandemic, but it doesn't mean we are safe." The crisis has exposed the "ferocious power" of the meat industry, as well as the "disrespectful" way in which the disease has been handled by governments and the media. "The media have behaved like terrorists," de Bellaigue writes. "They have exploited the fear and panic to push their agenda and profit from it." The crisis has also exposed the "disrespectful" way in which the disease has been handled by governments and the media. "The media have exploited the fear and panic to push their agenda and profit from it." Click here for more on the crisis.

– New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo is calling for a special prosecutor to investigate the death of an NYPD officer who was struck by a train while off duty, the New York Daily News reports. Police say 28-year-old officer Miodrag Vujicic was killed in the line of duty when he was struck by a train near the George Washington Bridge. Vujicic's family says he was hit in the back of the head with the train's conductor's baton. "It was a terrible tragedy for Officer Vujicic and his family," Cuomo said in a statement. "Our condolences go out to his family."

– The FDA has issued a warning about a potentially dangerous new drug that some are calling "flesh-eating," reports the Wall Street Journal. The Food and Drug Administration says the generic version of hydroxyzine, or hydroxyzine, that is being tested is similar to the active ingredient in hydroxyzine, which has been linked to an increased risk of infections in elderly people and people with weakened immune systems.

– Health officials around the globe are closely watching an outbreak of a new kind of flu that has killed at least 60 people in Mexico and infected seven in the United States. In Mexico, where the outbreak began, the death toll has risen to 60 and the country has declared a state of emergency, the AP reports. The number of US cases has risen to seven. The World Health Organization has urged people to avoid nonessential travel to Mexico.

– Kathleen Sebelius was sworn in as health secretary today in an Oval Office ceremony attended by President Obama, just hours after the Senate confirmed her nomination. Sebelius, a former Kansas governor, is the nation's first female health secretary and the first openly gay one, the AP reports. "I am humbled and honored to serve President Obama and the American people in this new role," she said in a statement. "I look forward to working with the president and the entire administration to ensure that the American people have access to high-quality, affordable health care."

– Egypt has started culling herds of pigs as a precaution against swine flu, even though the World Health Organization says there's no risk of infection from eating pork. The move comes after the UN criticized Egypt's decision to cull the herds, saying it was a "mistake," Reuters reports. Egypt's agriculture minister said the move was necessary because of resistance from farmers. "The situation in Egypt is difficult," he said. "The decision was taken in the interest of national security."

– Mexico’s health minister has some advice for his countrymen: Don’t wear neckties anymore. “We should all loosen our neckties,” said Jesus Murillo Karam, according to Reuters. “They should take them off entirely.” Murillo Karam was speaking after the country’s first death from the H1N1 virus.

– The US military's top general in Iraq is resigning, Gen. David Petraeus announced today. Petraeus will step down as head of the US Central Command at the end of this month, and will be replaced by Gen. Martin Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Petraeus had been expected to take over as Petraeus' successor, but he announced his resignation in a letter to President Obama today. "I have decided to step down as head of the Central Command," Petraeus wrote. "Effective immediately, I will be replaced by Gen. Martin Dempsey, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff." – In the wake of the Boston Marathon bombing, President Bush said, "Either you are with us, or you are with the terrorists." Well, Boston Marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev apparently disagrees. In an interview with NBC's Meet the Press, Tsarnaev said, "I don't think that's true. I don't think they were with us. I think they were with al-Qaeda." He added, "I don't know if they were with us at all. I don't think they were with us at all in the United States of America." Tsarnaev was convicted of second-degree murder in the Tamerlan Tsarnaev case, and was sentenced to life in prison.

– A German musician and anti-fascist activist who jumped to his death from a London bridge has been identified as 21-year-old Steffen Andersch, the Telegraph reports. Andersch was a singer, guitarist, activist, and photographer who fought fascism in his homeland and was passionate about the fight against fascism in London. The cause of his death isn't clear, but police say he jumped to his death from the River Thames bridge on Friday.

– In 2003, Robert Fisk published The Great War for Civilization, a book he'd written for nearly 30 years as a journalist in the Middle East. For 16 of those years he's chronicled the betrayals and treachery and deceit of Middle East history, nurturing this excessively long book—a real war and peace, but with precious little peace. Now, in the wake of the Boston Marathon bombing, Fisk is out with a new book, The Terrorists of Boston: Inside the World of Khorasan Group, an account of the terrorists' training, planning, and execution in the US and around the world. Fisk says he was inspired to write the book after reading about the Boston Marathon bombing in the New York Times. "I thought, 'There must be something here,'" he says. "I didn't know what I was going to write about. I didn't know what kind of book I was going to write. I didn't know what kind of country I was going to write about. I didn't know what kind of world I was going to live in. I didn't know what kind of regime I was going to live in. I didn't know what kind of country I was going to live in."

– DHL, the world's largest express delivery company, has admitted that some parts of Britain have been cut off from deliveries due to the Iraq war, the Telegraph reports. The company said it was working to resolve the problem, but admitted that some areas had been cut off entirely. "We are working closely with our delivery drivers to resolve the issue as soon as possible," said a spokesman.

– At the Venice Film Festival this week, the line that has become the most talked about was not a line about food or drink—it was a line about death. In fact, it was the first time a line about death had been mentioned during the festival, reports the Los Angeles Times. The line—"A glass of wine is worth a life"—was written and directed by Hans Christian Andersen, the author of Andersen's fairy tale The Snow Queen. – Britain's former ambassador to Iraq, who was knighted and made an ambassador in his own right last year, has died at the age of 69, the BBC reports. Carne Ross, who served as Britain's highest-ranking diplomat in Iraq from 2001 to 2003, was shot dead in his office in the Iraqi city of Falluja on Nov. 8, just days after the US military launched its largest-ever assault on the city, killing 1,200 insurgents. Ross, who was knighted in honor of Winston Churchill in 2003, died of a heart attack, according to the Telegraph.

– The US isn't the only country with a problem with foreign ownership of companies. Britain, meanwhile, has a problem with foreign ownership of companies. Halliburton and Bechtel, two American engineering giants, have won a huge deal to design and build Britain's new aircraft carriers, the Telegraph reports. British Prime Minister David Cameron is furious about the deal, which he sees as part of a US strategy to take over the world's No. 1 market for military equipment. "This is not about taking over the world—this is about taking over Britain," he said. "We're not taking over America. We're not taking over Europe. We're not taking over Russia. We're not taking over China. We're not taking over South Korea. We're not taking over Indonesia. We're not taking over Turkey. We're not taking over Iraq. We're not taking over Afghanistan. We're not taking over Somalia. We're not taking over Yemen. We're not taking over Somalia."

– British PM Tony Blair is calling for an end to the war in Iraq and says he will not seek a third term in office, the Telegraph reports. Blair made the comments in an interview with the BBC's Andrew Marr show. "I will not seek a third term," he said. "There has to be a limit to what a prime minister can do." Blair, who joined the US-led invasion of Iraq in 2003, has said he will not seek re-election this year.

– Michael Howard's latest movie, Turtles Can Fly, is an anti-war film without slogans—and that's what makes it different from other anti-war films, the director tells the Los Angeles Times. The story is about a group of US troops stationed in Iraq, played by Shia LaBeouf and Josh Brolin, who end up falling in love. "It's an anti-war movie without slogans," says Howard. "It's not an anti-war movie because it's anti-war, it's an anti-war movie because it's anti-war because it's an anti-war movie without slogans." LaBeouf and Brolin star in the film, which was written by and directed by Howard.

– Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction in his possession when the US invaded Iraq in 2003, according to a new report from the Iraq Survey Group. The group's chief, Charles Duelfer, has returned to the US and will deliver a final report in the spring that will be almost identical to the interim assessment he delivered to Congress last October, reports the Los Angeles Times. Duelfer's report will call for the release of Iraqi scientists still being questioned by the US military, who still believe Saddam had weapons of mass destruction at the time of the invasion.

– The ruins of Babylon were handed over to Iraq’s government today, more than four years after US troops desecrated and contaminated the site. The US military’s infamous construction of a base in the ancient city’s ruins “must rank as one of the most reckless acts of cultural vandalism in recent memory,” says a report released today by the British Museum. The base’s construction “caused widespread damage and severe contamination to the remains of the ancient city of Babylon,” the report states. Today marked the handover of control of the site to Iraqi authorities, the AP reports.

– The first British soldier to face court-martial over the abuse of Iraqi prisoners is due to go on trial today, along with two others accused in the same incident. The soldiers, all members of the 1st Battalion the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers, are accused of repeatedly punching and kicking detainees in the head and face, and of using a flashlight to rape a detainee in another incident, the Telegraph reports. A video of one of the soldiers punching a detainee in the head was shown to a court martial in Germany last week. The other two soldiers are accused of using a flashlight to rape a detainee in another incident.

– The US military plans to send 18 armed robots to Iraq in March or April to help fight the "war on terror," reports the Guardian. The robots will be stationed at bases around the country and will be able to move freely between bases and Iraqi security forces. The move comes as the US plans to withdraw most of its troops from Iraq by the end of next year. Britain, meanwhile, is considering criminal charges against nine soldiers accused of abuse in Iraq, reports the Observer.

– Anti-war activist Cindy Sheehan has been arrested in Britain for protesting outside George W. Bush's ranch in Texas more than 10 years ago. The 48-year-old Sheehan, whose son was killed in Iraq, was charged with disorderly conduct and public drunkenness, the Telegraph reports. She was also accused of spitting on a police officer and damaging a gate at a police station. She has been in Britain since last year.

– George W. Bush’s inauguration is expected to cost up to $50 million, making it one of the biggest parties in American history—but half of the country will be left out, critics say. The extravagant celebration will be “an unashamed celebration of Red America’s victory over Blue America,” says Fred Halliday, a leading expert on international affairs. “It’s time to bin the past,” he tells the Los Angeles Times. “We are still infected by Cold War ills: an arrogant West, shabby dictators, naive protests.”

– Al-Jazeera has been named the fifth most influential brand in the world, behind Apple, Google, Ikea, and Starbucks, in a survey by a worldwide branding consultancy. The Arab news channel had the fifth largest impact on the lives of 1,984 readers of Interbrand's Brandchannel.com, behind Apple, Google, Ikea, and Starbucks. – A German court has ordered the release of a journalist who was kidnapped in Baghdad in 2005 and accused of spying for the West, the Independent reports. The journalist, 33-year-old Juliagreet Mueller, was seized as she interviewed local people on the street. Mueller was working for an Italian newspaper when she was kidnapped. "She was kidnapped by a group of armed men who threatened to kill her if she didn't stop reporting on the situation in Iraq," said a spokesman for Germany's Federal Criminal Office. Mueller, who was born in Germany and moved to Iraq when she was 12, had been working for an Italian newspaper based in Baghdad.

– The head of the UN food program in Iraq and a senior UN official who dealt with contracts for the program have been suspended following an independent investigation that accused them of misconduct, a UN spokesman said yesterday. Benon Sevan, who was in charge of the $ 64 billion—LRB- # 34.5 billion—RRB- humanitarian program, and Joseph Stephanides, who heads the UN security council affairs division, were informed on Friday that they had been suspended with pay, the UN spokesman said.

– CNN's top news executive has resigned after accusing the US military of deliberately targeting journalists in Iraq, the AP reports. Eason Jordan said he was resigning to prevent the news giant being unfairly tarnished by his remarks, which he claims were misinterpreted. Jordan, who was CNN's executive VP for news, said he was resigning to prevent the news giant from being unfairly tarnished by his remarks, which he claims were misinterpreted.

– American soldiers traumatized by their time in Iraq and Afghanistan are to be offered the drug ecstasy to help free them of flashbacks and recurring nightmares. The US food and drug administration has given the go-ahead for the soldiers to be included in an experiment to see if MDMA, the active ingredient in ecstasy, can treat post-traumatic stress disorder, the Guardian reports. Photos have emerged of US forces in Afghanistan engaged in widespread Abu Ghraib-style abuse, taking "trophy photographs" of detainees and carrying out rape and sexual humiliation. Documents obtained by the Guardian contain evidence that such abuses took place in the main detention center at Bagram, near the capital Kabul, as well as at a smaller US installation near the southern city of Kandahar.

– NATO's 28 member states are meeting in Brussels today for a two-day summit, and Ukraine's president is making a surprise appearance. Viktor Yushchenko is expected to announce that his country is pulling out of the Ukraine-Russia nuclear deal, reports the Guardian. Yushchenko says he has decided to skip the summit to protest NATO's "illegal" eviction of his country from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

– Britain's Daily Mail has apologized for publishing a front-page story about a child soldier's death in Iraq that led to the resignation of Prime Minister Tony Blair. "We deeply regret that our actions have led to the death of a child and we apologize for the distress this has caused his family and friends," the paper said in a statement. The story, which ran in the May 1961 Observer, led to the resignation of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Blair, who was prime minister at the time, was criticized for the newspaper's coverage of the soldier's death.

– The US military's top lawyer in Iraq has resigned in the wake of the release of the graphic Abu Ghraib video, the AP reports. Gen. Stephen Sedley, the top US military lawyer in Iraq, stepped down from his post yesterday. He had been charged with dereliction of duty in connection with the release of the video, which shows US soldiers beating and torturing detainees in the Iraqi prison. Sedley had been in charge of the Pentagon's Office of Special Counsel before his resignation.

– A former detainee at the infamous Abu Ghraib prison says he was beaten, starved, and tortured to such a degree that he considered suicide, the New York Times reports. "I thought I was going to die," said Raheem al-Jibouri. "I thought I was going to be killed. I thought I was going to be raped. I was beaten so badly that I thought I was going to die." Jibouri, who says he was held at Abu Ghraib for two months before he was transferred to a US military prison, told the Guardian that he was beaten so badly that he thought he was going to die. "I was beaten so badly that I thought I was going to die," he said. "I thought I was going to be raped. I was beaten so badly that I thought I was going to die. I was beaten so badly that I thought I was going to pass out." He said that after he was transferred to a US military prison, he was beaten so badly that he thought he was going to pass out. – British soldier Johnson Beharry was awarded the Victoria Cross last week, making him the first British soldier to receive the nation's highest military honor since the Falklands War. But the 25-year-old's story raises a question: Why did he do it? In a piece for the Guardian, Peter Beaumont and Jason Burke ask the question: "What factors—physical, psychological, psychological and moral—create a heroic act?" The answer: Beharry's age, the fact that he was wounded three times, and the fact that he was on his first tour of duty in Iraq. Beaumont and Burke also note that Beharry is the first British soldier to receive the Victoria Cross since the Falklands War, and that the last British soldier to receive the award was also on his first tour of duty in Iraq. The full article is here.

– The father of a British soldier killed in Iraq has launched a political attack against Prime Minister Tony Blair, saying the war was "illegal and immoral." "I've always been a great fan of Muhammad Ali and his philosophy," Reg Keys tells the Telegraph. "I'll hold Blair to account." Keys, who says he was never interested in politics until his son Tom was killed in Iraq, says he plans to hold Blair to account for supporting the "illegal and immoral" war. "I'll hold Blair to account for the fact that his son was killed in a war he believes was illegal and immoral," Keys says.

– The Pentagon's top interrogator in Iraq authorized 29 interrogation techniques that included sleep manipulation, stress positions, and the use of dogs to "exploit Arab fears," according to documents obtained by the Guardian. A memo signed by Lt. Gen. Ricardo Sanchez, who was in charge of US military operations in Iraq, approved 12 techniques that exceeded limits in the army's own field manual and four that he admitted risked falling foul of international law, the Geneva conventions, or accepted standards on the humane treatment of prisoners.

– Paul Wolfowitz is set to be named as the next president of the World Bank today, in a unanimous decision by the bank's 24-member board, the Guardian reports. Wolfowitz, who served as deputy secretary of state under George W. Bush, will be the firstowitz to head the bank since Frenchmanophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophileophile in the late 1970s and early 1980s. – Iraq's parliament has voted to impeach Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki over allegations that he ordered the beheading of an Iraqi journalist. The move comes a day after Maliki's government announced that it would allow journalists to return to the country, though they would have to register as Iraqi citizens. The move is likely to anger US officials who believe Maliki ordered the beheading of Haider al-Abadi in retaliation for the US raid that killed Osama bin Laden. The vote is expected to be easily approved by Iraq's parliament.

– Iraq's prime minister says the US military has pulled out of the northern city of Mosul, CNN reports. Nouri al-Maliki made the announcement during a visit to the US Embassy in Baghdad, where he met with President Obama. He said the decision to pull out of the city, 360 miles north of the capital, was made after intelligence reports indicated that al-Qaeda in Iraq was planning attacks against US facilities in the region. He said the US has also concluded that al-Qaeda in Iraq is responsible for the attack on the US embassy.

– The US military's top general in Iraq has resigned, effective immediately, CNN reports. Gen. David Petraeus, who became the top US commander in Iraq last month, will step down from his post effective immediately. Petraeus had been expected to take over for Gen. – A 14-year-old British girl has become the youngest person ever to be convicted of a crime related to the Falkland Islands war with Argentina, the Guardian reports. Lucy Mugglestone, who was 17 when she was convicted of attempting to smuggle weapons into Argentina in 2002, was sentenced to 18 months in prison last year. Her conviction was overturned on appeal, and she was released in June of this year. Mugglestone's conviction was related to an incident in which she was found with a large amount of marijuana and drug-related items in her room at her family's vacation home on the south coast of Argentina, the Telegraph reported at the time.

– An American aid worker killed in a car bombing in Iraq 10 years ago is being hailed as a hero today. Marla Ruzicka, 28, was a tireless advocate for victims of the Afghanistan and Iraq wars, collecting millions of dollars in compensation from the US government. She was killed in a blast near Baghdad's airport on April 19, 2005. " Marla Ruzicka was an extraordinary, one - person American aid agency, who worked tirelessly to get compensation for victims of the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq," writes Peter Popham in the Guardian. "Though only 28 when she died, she was an unusual mixture of charm, ebullience, adventure—seeking and tireless dedication to helping ordinary people whose lives had been shattered."

– The US military is considering allowing women to fight on the front lines in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Telegraph reports. The move would mark a big change for the military, which has allowed women to serve on the back lines in support of operations in Iraq and Afghanistan since the 2003 invasion of Iraq. But it would also mark a major policy shift for the Pentagon, which has long allowed women to serve only in special operations forces.

– A British soldier who was wounded in Iraq and left for dead has been identified as Dave Corrigan, a 24-year-old father of two who was on his first tour of duty in the country, the Telegraph reports. Corrigan was shot in the back of the head by an Iraqi soldier on May 2, 2005, and left for dead in a field four days later. He was a rifleman in the 1st Battalion, Royal Regiment of Fusiliers, which is part of the UK's National Guard. A fellow soldier who was with Corrigan at the time of the shooting has been identified as Private First Class Anthony Wakefield, who was on his first tour of duty in Iraq and was shot in the back of the head by an Iraqi soldier as he tried to run away. The Italian government has determined that Wakefield was a CIA agent and has called for an investigation into the shooting, the Guardian reports. The British government has not commented on the report.

– In the wake of the Boston Marathon bombing, Mitt Romney has taken flak for saying the US should "do more to prevent tragedies like this"—and he's not alone. A new poll finds that more than two-thirds of Americans don't think the US should do more to prevent tragedies like the Boston Marathon bombing, the Guardian reports. The survey by Public Policy Polling finds that 63% of Americans don't think the US should do more to prevent tragedies like the Boston Marathon bombing, and 61% don't think the US should send more troops to Iraq. The poll also finds that more than half of Americans don't think the US has done enough to prevent tragedies like the Boston Marathon.

– The head of Britain's MI6 is in hot water after a former weapons inspector accused him of trying to seduce the body tasked with finding Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction in Iraq, the Telegraph reports. Dr. Rod Barton, who was a senior weapons inspector when the Iraq Survey Group (ISG) was formed after the 2003 US-led invasion, says MI6 chief Sir John Scarlett and a top Ministry of Defense official intervened in a report by the ISG early last year. Barton, who is now a professor at the University of Nottingham, says Scarlett and the official tried to get the ISG to drop the report's allegations that the Iraqi government had destroyed weapons of mass destruction. He says the MI6 official told him, "You're not going to find any weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. You're not going to find any weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. You're not going to find any weapons of mass destruction in Iraq."

– British politician George Galloway, who has been accused of trading oil for Saddam Hussein's regime, went to the US Senate this week and delivered what the Daily Record calls a "stunning ferocity" against his accusers. "Love him or loathe him, no one can doubt George Galloway has got guts—and he's got a point," the Scottish newspaper writes. "He confronted his accusers in the US Senate yesterday, denying any involvement in Iraqi oil trades and using the occasion to unleash an indictment of the war with a stunning ferocity." The senator who first accused Galloway, a Respect MP, of selling oil for Saddam has since apologized.

– It's been more than a year since a British tabloid snapped a photo of Saddam Hussein in his underwear, and the former Iraqi leader has finally spoken out. In an interview with the Telegraph, he says he doesn't know how the photo ended up in the hands of a tabloid. "I don't know how it got into the hands of a newspaper," he says. "I don't know how it got into the hands of the president of the United States. I don't know how it got into the hands of the British tabloid Sun." He says he doesn't know who leaked the photo to the Sun, but he's sure it's a British tabloid.

– A French judge has ordered the country's president and first lady to appear in court next month to explain why they haven't turned over their passports to US authorities, reports the BBC. The judge says the pair must explain why they haven't handed over their travel documents to the US Embassy in Paris. President Nicolas Sarkozy and first lady Carla Bruni-Sarkozy were ordered to appear in court on May 25 to explain why they haven't handed over their passports. The judge says the passports are being held in a secure facility in Paris.

– Malaysia's Mahathir Mohamad has lashed out at President Bush and British Prime Minister Tony Blair, calling them "rogue regimes" bent on "terrorizing innocent civilians." Mahathir, the world's oldest elected Muslim leader, said he was "disappointed" that Blair had been re-elected after joining the US invasion of Iraq, the Telegraph reports. Mahathir, who became Malaysia's prime minister in 2003, said he believes Jews rule the world by proxy and that the US is a "rogue nation" bent on terrorizing innocent civilians.

– Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein have a new book out, and it's a doozy. The pair sat down for an interview with Rebecca Solnit of Salon, and Solnit offered up this jaw-dropping tidbit: "In the Washington Post in 1973, there was a reporter by the name of Carl Bernstein, and Bob Woodward was a reporter by the name of Rorschach Bernstein." So what does Bernstein think of Woodward's new book, The Woodwards: An Unlikely Ballerina? Solnit didn't buy it. "I don't think it's very good," she said. "I don't think it's very interesting. I don't think it has anything to do with politics. I don't think it has anything to do with history. I don't think it has anything to do with the Vietnam War. I don't think it has anything to do with the Cold War. I don't think it has anything to do with what's going on in the world today." Read the full interview here.

– A British soldier has been charged with shooting and killing an Iraqi man while on patrol in southern Iraq in June 2005, the BBC reports. Lance Corporal Barry Singleton, 23, allegedly fired 12 times at the man as he drove through a checkpoint, killing him and seriously wounding his wife and two children. A military investigation found that Singleton, who was off duty at the time, had been following the man's vehicle for more than a mile when he pulled up next to it and opened fire. Singleton's commanding officer said he believed the man was reaching for a weapon, but the soldier's lawyer said his client believed the man was reaching for a knife. The charges against Singleton were announced yesterday. Singleton is the second British soldier to be charged with murder in Iraq since the US-led invasion in 2003.

– US and Iraqi officials have held their first direct talks with insurgents since the US-led invasion of Iraq in 2005, the Guardian reports. A US embassy official in Baghdad said negotiations were under way with “elements of the resistance,” an apparent softening of the Bush administration’s opposition to negotiations.

– Iran's presidential election is today, and analysts are predicting a landslide victory for moderate cleric Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, an ally of supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. But a late surge for reform candidate Mostafa Moin, a former education minister, is raising doubts, the New York Times reports. Mostafa Moin, 54, has never held elected office and was banned from running for office in the past over his alleged links to Israeli intelligence. Khamenei, meanwhile, is widely expected to win re-election.

– The war in Iraq is creating a new breed of Islamic jihadists who could go on to destabilise other countries, according to a CIA report. The CIA believes Iraq to be potentially worse than Afghanistan, which produced thousands of jihadists in the 1980s and 1990s. Two years after the Iraq insurgency began in 2003, sceptics asked: 'Is this the new Vietnam?'' Current US megalomania is rooted in the Puritan colonists' certainties.

– The US military has been in contact with some of the leaders of the Iraqi insurgency in an attempt to stem the violence that has killed hundreds of people this week, defense chief Donald Rumsfeld told the Senate yesterday. He said the military had been trying to contact anti-American cleric Muqtada al-Sadr as well as other leaders of the Shiite militias blamed for much of the violence. "We have been in contact with some of the leaders of the Iraqi insurgency," Rumsfeld told the Senate, adding that the insurgency could go on for at least a decade and that the military had been trying to contact some of its leaders in an attempt to quell the violence.

– Democrats were quick to pounce on President Bush's speech last night, in which he linked the Iraq war to the 9/11 attacks and warned that withdrawal would leave the US open to more terrorist attacks. "The president exploited the sacred ground of September 11," said Harry Reid, accusing Bush of "exploiting the anniversary of one of the most devastating days in our nation's history." The full text of the speech is here.

– Coca-Cola has returned to Iraq after a nearly 40-year absence, triggering a cola war in a lucrative but potentially hostile market. The company's chief executive, Muhtar Kent, met with Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki and other government officials in Baghdad yesterday to discuss the return of the Coca-Cola Co. to the country, the Guardian reports. "We are very pleased to be back in Iraq," he said. "We have a great deal of respect for the government of Iraq and the people of Iraq." Maliki, for his part, said he welcomed the return of the Coca-Cola Co. to Iraq, the AP reports.

– British Prime Minister David Cameron is calling for an emergency meeting of the G8 to discuss the terrorist attacks in London and Dublin, the Guardian reports. "We must do everything in our power to prevent such attacks from happening again," he said in a speech in Northern Ireland today. "We must do everything in our power to prevent terrorism from happening in our country." The G8 is a group of leading industrialized countries, including the US. The last time the group met was in 2005, when Cameron was prime minister.

– The mother of one of the three suicide bombers who killed himself and five others in last week's attacks on London has made an emotional appeal for her son's safe return. Marie Fatayi stood near the spot where her 26-year-old son, Anthony, is believed to have been killed in the attacks, the Guardian reports. "It is an insult to the dead to deny the link with Iraq Tony Blair put his own people at risk in the service of a foreign power," she said. "My son is still missing and I would like to appeal for information on his whereabouts."

– Britain’s involvement in the US-led wars in Iraq and Afghanistan contributed to the 2005 terrorist attacks in London, according to a prominent independent thinktank. “The key problem in the UK for preventing terrorism is that the country is riding as a pillion passenger with the United States in the war against terror,” says the Chatham House organization, which includes leading academics and former civil servants. Two-thirds of Britons believe there is a link between Tony Blair’s decision to invade Iraq and the London bombings, despite government claims to the contrary, according to a Guardian/ICM poll published today.

– Britain's decision to prosecute three soldiers for war crimes in Iraq is "a crushing blow for an army known and respected worldwide for its peacekeeping prowess and discipline," writes John Lichfield in the Telegraph. "In the Lords last week, former chiefs of defense staff lined up one after another to harangue the Ministry of Defense for succumbing to 'political correctness' by allowing British soldiers to be subjected to legal constraints by lawyers who had no idea what it was like to face not a conventional enemy, but insurgents in Iraq, a uniquely dangerous security environment." British soldiers are "scared to act and morale will suffer" if they face prosecution, says Lichfield. "It is time to fight back."

– The family of Jean Charles de Menezes, the Brazilian man shot dead by police in London in 2005 after he was mistaken for a suicide bomber, says he was not wearing a heavy jacket that might have concealed a bomb. The Metropolitan Police yesterday admitted that de Menezes did not jump the ticket barrier when challenged by armed plainclothes police, the Telegraph reports. Police say they shot de Menezes in the head because they believed he was about to kill someone.

– One of the suspects in last month's failed terrorist attacks in London says the bombings were inspired by Britain's involvement in the Iraq war. Hussain Osman, arrested in Rome on Friday, says the men watched hours of TV footage showing Iraqi widows and children killed in the conflict, along with images of civilians killed in the conflict, the Telegraph reports. He also claims the plot was inspired by al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden.

– In the years since the July 7, 2005, terror attacks in London, there have been many theories and explanations as to what went wrong. Now, researchers at Oxford University say they've come up with one big one: The attacks weren't an "individual act of terrorism," but an episode in a worldwide conflict, reports the Guardian. The paper, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, argues that the July 7, 2005, attacks were part of a larger conflict going on around the world, and that al-Qaeda and other terrorist groups had a hand in the attacks. (Read the full article here.)

– Britain's former foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has died after collapsing while walking in the Scottish hills. Cook, 59, was airlifted to a hospital in Inverness, where he died last night, the Telegraph reports. Cook, a Labour MP, served as foreign secretary from 2001 to 2005. In 2003, he delivered "one of the most important addresses in modern Westminster history" in which he resigned as an MP, notes the Independent.

– The leader of Iraq's Shia Muslim minority has been killed in an attack on his office in Baghdad, the AP reports. Police say Muqtada al-Sadr's office was hit by a roadside bomb near the city of Samarra, 60 miles north of the Iraqi capital. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack. Sadr's office is the country's top Shiite religious leader.

– Iraq's parliament has approved a draft constitution that gives women far more rights than men, despite opposition from women's rights groups and the US, the Telegraph reports. The constitution, which must be approved by at least two-thirds of Iraq's parliament, will give women more rights than men, including the right to vote and hold public office. But Western feminist groups and some Iraqi women activists fear that Islamic law, if enshrined as a main source of legislation, will be used to restrict their rights, particularly in relation to marriage, divorce and inheritance.

– A British MP has introduced a bill in Parliament that would make it legal for the UK to go to war with any country that doesn't sign up for the fight, the Guardian reports. The bill, which would bring Britain's entry into the first world war into line with the modern world, was introduced by Clare Short. It would also allow the UK to declare war on any country that doesn't sign up. Short says she wants to bring conflict law in line with the modern world, but the bill is unlikely to get much support in the House of Commons. (Click here for more on Short's bill.)

– When it comes to the US-Venezuela relationship, it's all about Hugo Chavez, writes Andrew Sullivan in the Daily Beast. The Venezuelan president, a longtime friend of Fidel Castro, is a fierce critic of the US war in Iraq, and has long been a thorn in the side of the US—a fact highlighted this week when televangelist Pat Robertson called for his assassination. Sullivan calls Chavez "a thorn in the side of the US" because "he is a friend of Fidel Castro, a fierce critic of the war in Iraq, and wants to spread revolutionary fervor throughout South America."

– Britain's top official warned his Cabinet colleagues that the Iraq war was "fueling Muslim extremism" in the UK a year before the July 7, 2005, bombings in London, according to a leaked letter obtained by the Observer. The letter, written by the permanent undersecretary of the Foreign Office and obtained by the newspaper, says the bombings were likely the work of Sunni Muslim extremists inspired by the Iraq war. "There is no doubt that the conflict in Iraq has led to a rise in the level of extremism in this country," the letter says. "This has in turn led to a rise in terrorism in this country." Britain's government has repeatedly denied that the Iraq war made the country a target for terrorists.

– The man accused of plotting to blow up New York City landmarks, including the Statue of Liberty, has been charged with plotting a terrorist attack in the city, the New York Daily News reports. Police say 26-year-old Diangelo Enriquez-Rodrigo, who is also accused of plotting to kill President Obama and blow up the United Nations, is being held on $1 million bail in New York City. Enriquez-Rodrigo's lawyer says his client, who has pleaded not guilty, is innocent and "vigorously" defending himself against the charges.

– As New Orleans begins to dig out from the devastation of Hurricane Katrina, the Times-Picayune takes a look at the history of the city's levees, which were originally designed to handle a Category 3 hurricane. They were never designed to handle a Category 4, and many of them broke during the storm. Why did the levees fail? It's all due to "manmade engineering" in the Mississippi delta, explains the American Society of Civil Engineers. Click here for more on the history of New Orleans' levees.

– The Iraqi government has ordered all remaining troops out of the country by the end of next month, in what it says is an effort to cut down on the violence that has killed more than 1,000 people in the past week. Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki's office said today that all remaining troops will be withdrawn from the country by the end of March, the AP reports. Analysts say that if the withdrawal goes ahead as planned, it will mark a significant reduction in the violence that has plagued Iraq since the US-led invasion in 2003. Analysts say that if the withdrawal goes ahead as planned, it will mark a significant reduction in the violence that has plagued Iraq since the US-led invasion in 2003.

– Christopher Hitchens and George Galloway debated the merits and demerits of the Iraq war in New York last night, and the back-and-forth was nasty from the get-go. Hitchens called the British MP a "disgrace" and a "sludge" who had "a trail of slime" and was "all washed up, like Sonny Liston," according to the Guardian. Galloway fired back that the Hitchens "sludge" is a "liar" who has "no credibility at all." The two also clashed over the merits and demerits of the war in Iraq in general, and the Sept. 11 attacks in particular. (Click here for more on their back-and-forth.)

– British writer Christopher Hitchens and anti-war British MP George Galloway squared off in New York last night in a sold-out debate that drew hundreds of people to Manhattan’s Mason Hall, the Telegraph reports. Galloway, whose latest book is called The Death and Life of George W. Bush, accused Hitchens of “anti-Semitism” and said he was “appalled” by the author’s support of the US war in Iraq. “Christopher Hitchens is a war criminal,” Galloway told the crowd. “He’s a war criminal in every sense of the word.”

– Armed dolphins trained by the US military to shoot terrorists and pinpoint spies underwater may be missing in the Gulf of Mexico, reports the Observer, in an odd tale that may or may not be true. The US military has been training dolphins to shoot terrorists and pinpoint spies underwater in the Gulf of Mexico since the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. But now that the oil and gas industry is struggling, the dolphins may be gone for good.

– If you've ever wanted to know what it's like to be the leader of the free world, you're in luck. The World Economic Forum has just released its annual list of the world's most powerful people, and for the first time ever, there's a list of the world's richest people. The list includes none other than Warren Buffett, who is No. 1 in the Forbes list of the world's richest people with a net worth of $7.5 billion. It's the first time the list has been released since it was created in 2000, and it includes not just the world's richest people, but also some of the world's most powerful business leaders, politicians, celebrities, and other bigwigs. The list is based on responses from around the world to the question, "What is it like to be the leader of the free world?" The richest people on the list are: Bill Gates, with a net worth of $30.7 billion; Carlos Slim Helu, with a net worth of $22.3 billion; and Amancio Ortega, who has a net worth of $12.3 billion. The list is based on responses from around the world to the question, "What is it like to be the leader

– The CIA planned to use a UN weapons inspection to overthrow Saddam Hussein—and it didn't succeed, according to an ex-Marine who says he was involved in the plan. In his first detailed account of the CIA's role in the Iraq war, Scott Ritter says the agency wanted to remove Saddam's regime from power through the use of weapons of mass destruction, the Telegraph reports. But the plan didn't work out so well, he says, because intelligence officers didn't understand how a weapons inspection could possibly go wrong. Ritter, who was involved in the hunt for Saddam's weapons of mass destruction before he was killed in Iraq in 2003, says he was ordered to destroy evidence of the weapons before he was allowed to leave the country, the New York Daily News reports. "I was ordered to destroy all evidence of the weapons of mass destruction that I found in Iraq," he says. "I was told I was going to die if I didn't destroy these weapons. I was told I was going to be executed if I didn't destroy these weapons. I was told that if I didn't destroy these weapons, I was going to be executed.
