– A small amount of rabbit fever was detected on the National Mall in Washington, DC, during protests against the Iraq war, health officials say. The non-contagious disease, which causes sudden fever, chills, muscle aches, and pneumonia, is easily treated with antibiotics, the Telegraph reports.

– It's not every day that a celebrity dies at age 69, but that's exactly what happened to M Scott Peck. The psychiatrist, who made millions with his first book, The Road Less Travelled, died of complications from Parkinson's disease at his home in Woodland Hills, Calif., reports the Los Angeles Times. He was 69. His cause of death hasn't been determined.

– In the wake of the Charlie Hebdo massacre, the New York Times takes a look at the people, places, and ideas that are making headlines in the wake of the terror attack. Here's a look at some of the most talked-about stories of the day: French President Franois Hollande is calling the attack "an act of terrorism," and he's warning that it could be just the first of many. "This is an act of war, an act of terrorism against our liberty and our way of life," he said in a televised address to the nation, according to the Guardian. "France is fighting a war against terrorism. And we will continue to fight it." French authorities say they've found a message on an Arabic website from the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, a "deranged Algerian outfit which is close to al-Qaeda," and that they're looking into possible links to the Charlie Hebdo attackers, the Telegraph reports. "This is not just an attack on freedom of speech, this is an attack on our way of life," said Hollande. "This is an act of terrorism against our way of life." President Obama has condemned the "cowardly" attack, calling it an "outrageous

– "I was a woman in a warrior's world." So writes Janis Karpinski, commander of Abu Ghraib prison when abuse at the Iraqi facility was exposed, in her new memoir. Karpinski, who became the first female general in the US military when she took charge of the prison in 2004, writes of her fury at being made the scapegoat in the scandal. "I rarely fell asleep in Baghdad," she writes of her time in the prison, where inmates were beaten and humiliated by their male superiors. "I was a woman in a warrior's world," she writes of her time in the Abu Ghraib prison, in her book, The Women's Army: An Unlikely Ballerina, out this week. "I was a woman in a warrior's world."

– Saddam Hussein's trial is set to begin today, more than three years after the US-led invasion that overthrew him. The trial will focus on the 1982 deaths of 148 people in the village of Dujail after an assassination attempt on the former president, reports the Guardian, which has background on the charges against him.

– The Guardian has confirmed that one of its journalists has been kidnapped in Iraq. Rory Carroll, 33, was working for the paper in Baghdad when he was seized by gunmen last night. "We can confirm that one of our journalists has been kidnapped in Baghdad," the paper said in a statement. "We are doing everything we can to locate him." Carroll, an experienced foreign correspondent, had been working on an interview with a victim of Saddam Hussein's regime.

– The leader of a Sunni insurgent group that has turned against al-Qaeda in Iraq has been arrested, the AP reports. Abu Theeb, leader of a band of Sunni insurgents that preys on US targets north of Baghdad, was taken into custody yesterday. He has publicly defied al-Qaeda in Iraq by actively supporting the referendum that voted to allow the US to stay in Iraq. Last week he openly defied al-Qaeda in Iraq by actively supporting the referendum.

– Relatives of some of those who died in the July 7 bombings are expected to boycott today's multi-faith service of remembrance at St. Paul's Cathedral. Families of a handful of the 52 men and women who died are understood to be planning to stay away because they feel overwhelmed by anger. The Telegraph has the details.

– Scooter Libby pleaded not guilty to five counts of lying and obstruction of justice in the CIA leak case yesterday, and the case is expected to delve deeply into President Obama's decision to go to war in Iraq. Libby is likely to be called as a witness in the trial, the Telegraph reports. He is accused of leaking the identity of a covert CIA operative to the media and of lying to a grand jury about his conversations with reporters.

– One year after US-led forces launched a devastating assault on the Iraqi city of Falluja, the Daily Mail takes a look back at what it calls "the destruction of Falluja was an act of barbarism that ranks alongside My Lai, Guernica, and Halabja." The name that lives in infamy—"the destruction of Falluja was an act of barbarism that ranks alongside My Lai, Guernica, and Halabja"—"lives in infamy" because it was used to refer to the Iraqi city that was attacked by US-led forces one year ago today. "The name that lives in infamy" is "filled with tattooed ex-soldiers, young former officers, and eastern European prostitutes," says the paper. "The bars are filled with tattooed ex-soldiers, young former officers, and eastern European prostitutes."

– Peter Hitchens has a new book out, and it's a doozy. It's called End Times, and it's the story of the end of the world as we know it, in the words of the Daily Mail. "We live in a land of End Times burglaries, muggings, swearing, pools of vomit, MRSA, rave parties and traveller encampments," writes Hitchens. "We live in a land of molten Old Testament fury shot through with visceral wit—we live in a land of End Times burglaries, muggings, swearing, pools of vomit, MRSA, rave parties and traveller encampments." (Click here for the full column.)

– Al-Jazeera is calling on the British and US governments to provide "a good explanation" for claims that George Bush considered bombing the network's headquarters in Qatar during the run-up to the Iraq war. A memo leaked in November 2005 claims that the US considered attacking al-Jazeera's offices in the capital of Qatar at the height of last year's Iraqi insurgency, the Guardian reports. The British government last night threatened newspapers with the Official Secrets Act if they revealed the contents of the document.

– Lawrence Wilkerson, former chief of staff to Colin Powell and one-time State Department official, thinks Dick Cheney may have committed a war crime when he oversaw the torture of detainees at Abu Ghraib. In a wide-ranging attack on the Bush administration on the BBC's Today program, Wilkerson accused the vice president of ordering the waterboarding of Abu Ghraib detainees and of knowing about the abuse of detainees at Abu Ghraib before the US invasion of Iraq in 2003. "I'm not saying he didn't know, but I'm not saying he didn't authorize it," Wilkerson said. "I'm just saying he didn't seem to know what he was doing."

– Israel has been secretly training members of Iraq's Kurdish minority to fight ISIS, according to an Israeli newspaper report. The Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper said that dozens of former members of Israel's elite and covert forces were training Kurdish fighters in anti-terrorism techniques. The report said that Israeli firms were carrying out military training and commercial activities in Kurdish areas of north Iraq, the Telegraph reports.

– Robert Downey Jr. has been ordered to stand trial for his alleged role in a plot to kill Queen Elizabeth II, the AP reports. A federal judge in Los Angeles ordered the Iron Man actor to stand trial for allegedly plotting to kill the monarch and his close friend George W. Bush. The plot involved a plot to kidnap and kill the queen, who was visiting Iraq for the G8 summit. Downey, who has a long history of legal troubles, was charged with attempted murder, conspiracy to commit murder, and impersonating a public official.

– President Bush said today that much of the intelligence leading up to the US invasion of Iraq was wrong, but that he took sole responsibility for ordering it because of the threat posed by Saddam Hussein. "Much of the pre-war intelligence on Iraq was wrong," Bush said in a speech at the Woodrow Wilson Center, "but I took sole responsibility for ordering it because it removed Saddam Hussein from power." He said the US would remain in Iraq "until victory is achieved," the Guardian reports.

– The US has been in Iraq for more than four years now, and in that time it's emerged as one of the most important nations in the world, writes James Meek in the Los Angeles Times. And he's not just calling it a "great war film"—he's calling it a " genre whose explosions keep going off in newspaper columns and political discourse long after the closing credits have rolled." So what makes a great war film? "First and foremost, a film has to tell a compelling story," says Meek, "and that story has to be told by people who are actually on the ground." And that's exactly what we've seen in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Pakistan. "We've seen a country that's come back from the brink to be a force for good in the world," says Meek. "We've seen a government that's come back from the brink to govern. We've seen a country that's come back from the brink to fight. We've seen a country that's come back from the brink to win." Read Meek's full column here.

– President Trump's tariff fight with China isn't going anywhere anytime soon, reports the Wall Street Journal. The White House has threatened to slap tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods if Beijing doesn't reduce its trade with the US. China has threatened to retaliate with tariffs of its own. Trump has said he wants to reduce the trade deficit with the US, but the White House says that won't happen until China agrees to reduce its tariffs on a range of American goods, from cars to semiconductors. The Journal notes that Trump has also threatened to slap tariffs on Chinese goods if it doesn't reduce its own trade with the US. (This story has been corrected to show that Trump has said he wants to reduce the deficit with the US, not increase it.)

– A grisly scene is unfolding in Baghdad, where Iraqi forces are battling insurgents in a high-security prison. At least nine people are dead, including some prisoners who are believed to be among the most dangerous in custody, according to the Iraqi government. The prison is just a few miles from the Green Zone, where US and Iraqi officials are meeting to discuss a possible deal to keep American troops in the country.

– With the unrest rocking the Middle East and North Africa, Moammar Gadhafi has decided to let his sons run the show. Saif al-Islam and Mutassim have taken to the streets of Libya’s second-largest city, Benghazi, and begun chanting, “Down with Gadhafi!” and “No to tyrant Moammar Gadhafi,” al-Jazeera reports. “They will rule until the last man, until the last woman, until the last bullet,” a protester tells CNN. Saif al-Islam, meanwhile, appeared on state TV today, declaring, “I am the leader of the nation and I will rule until the last man, until the last woman, until the last bullet,” according to al-Jazeera.

– Mikhail Gorbachev has joined the condemnation of Moammar Gadhafi's brutal crackdown on protesters in Libya. "Like you and many others around the world, I have seen very disturbing and shocking scenes, where Libyan authorities have been firing at demonstrators from warplanes and helicopters," the former Soviet leader said in a statement, condemning the "unacceptable bloodshed" and calling on Europe and the US to "respond to this situation very responsibly," CNN reports. The US is keeping a close watch on the situation and monitoring Gadhafi's son's speech Sunday night, in which he warned of a civil war if protesters didn't back down. "Like you and many others around the world, I have seen very disturbing and shocking scenes, where Libyan authorities have been firing at demonstrators from warplanes and helicopters," Gorbachev said.

– The UN Security Council has unanimously approved sanctions against Moammar Gadhafi's government for its violent crackdown on protesters, CNN reports. The sanctions include an arms embargo, an asset freeze, and a travel ban. The vote came as Gadhafi’s forces continued their assault on Zawiya, attacking the coastal city with tanks, artillery, and warplanes. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said he was "shocked" by the violence, which he said had killed more than 200 people over the past 24 hours, the AP reports. He called for an end to the "unspeakable brutality" of Gadhafi's security forces, and urged Libyans to defend themselves. Meanwhile, Mike Huckabee called the violence a "virtual genocide" and criticized President Obama for not doing more to stop it. "I think I 'd make it very clear that the United States is not going to stand by and watch a country slaughter its own people in cold blood, that there is a sense in which there is a virtual genocide going on," he said on CNN.

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi has told the BBC and ABC News that he won’t step down, even as his security forces continue to pound anti-government protesters in Tripoli. “My people will die for me,” he tells the BBC. “No one loves me, no one loves me,” he tells ABC, adding that al-Qaeda is to blame for the current chaos in the country. Gadhafi also told the BBC that Libyans will “take revenge” for the deaths of their countrymen at the hands of Gadhafi’s forces. Gadhafi’s forces are “at their best” in the capital, he said, but “we are facing a very difficult situation.” The Libyan government has frozen some $30 billion in government assets in the US and elsewhere, CNN reports, and UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon says he is ready to step up the pressure on Gadhafi.

– President Obama has authorized the use of US military and civilian aircraft to help Egyptians who have fled to Tunisia escape the unrest in Libya, CNN reports. Two C-130 cargo planes are en route to Cairo, with supplies meant to help with the humanitarian crisis in Libya. "The aspirations of the Libyan people for freedom, democracy, and dignity must be met," said Obama in a statement. "The United States is examining a full range of options, including a no-fly zone, in order to protect Americans and our citizens in Libya."

– The price of gas is rising fast in the US, CNN reports. The national average for a gallon of self-serve unleaded is $3.51, up 33 cents in the past two weeks. That’s the second-biggest two-week increase in the history of the gas market, notes the Lundberg Survey.

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi's forces bombed the oil port of Ras Lanuf today as part of a campaign to regain control of the east of the country, reports CNN. The strikes hit a key road leading into the city, which has been held by rebels for weeks. Gadhafi's forces are also believed to be targeting Zawiya, a city west of the capital that has seen some of the fiercest fighting.

– The Arab League has approved a no-fly zone over Libya, reports CNN. Arab League chief Amre Moussa made the announcement at a news conference at the League's headquarters in Doha, Qatar. He said the no-fly zone would go into effect "as soon as it is approved by the UN Security Council." The move comes as Gadhafi’s forces continue their assault on the capital city of Tripoli and on the oil port of Ras Lanuf. Click here for more.

– The US has joined the coalition targeting Moammar Gadhafi's forces in Libya, CNN reports. American ships and aircraft fired more than 110 Tomahawk Cruise missiles at more than 20 radar and communication sites inside the country. "We are not going after Gadhafi," said the chairman of the Joint Chiefs. "We are going after his air defenses, his ground forces, his command-and-control systems." The strikes were aimed at enforcing a no-fly zone to prevent Gadhafi's forces from attacking rebels. In other developments: In Benghazi, Gadhafi's forces shot down a rebel fighter jet and killed the pilot, CNN reports. The Libyan leader has vowed to fight back against the strikes, and his security forces are massing at the capital's airport, according to the New York Times. The Times reports that four of its journalists have been freed by Gadhafi's forces.

– Moammar Gadhafi has promised to release four New York Times journalists who were arrested while covering the Libyan civil war, the paper reports. Gadhafi’s son, Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, made the announcement in an interview with the paper. “ Lynsey Addario will be released,” he said, according to the New York Times. Addario, a female photographer, is one of the four Times journalists missing in Libya. All four have been confirmed to have been seized by Gadhafi’s security forces while covering the conflict in Benghazi and Ajdabiya. “As far as I can tell, Americans have not been provided with sufficient evidence of mass atrocities committed by the Gadhafi regime to justify a military intervention on humanitarian grounds alone,” says the paper’s managing editor. “ Nor has the administration made a case that the alternative to Gadhafi justifies the risk of removing him.”

– Coalition forces are closing in on Moammar Gadhafi's forces in Libya, but the US won't be taking the lead in enforcing a no-fly zone, Defense Secretary Robert Gates told CNN today. "We have done something like this, kind of on the fly before," Gates said. "There's no plan for any group or nation to take the lead, why there's no plan for any group or nation to take the lead." In other developments: Coalition forces are stepping up attacks on Gadhafi's troops in the western part of the country, the Wall Street Journal reports. The strikes are targeting Gadhafi's ground troops and command and control facilities. US ships and aircraft are stationed in the Mediterranean, ready to strike Gadhafi's air defenses and other military targets. In other developments: Coalition forces are stepping up attacks on Gadhafi's forces in the western part of the country, the New York Times reports. The strikes are targeting Gadhafi's ground troops and command and control facilities. US ships and aircraft are stationed in the Mediterranean, ready to strike Gadhafi's air defenses and other military targets. Coalition forces are also stepping up attacks on Gadhafi's

– The US should arm Libyan rebels so they can resist Moammar Gadhafi's forces, a rebel leader told CNN today. Angel Rabasa, leader of the Benghazi-based Libyan National Council, said that Gadhafi's ground forces are well-armed and well-equipped, and that the US should arm the rebels so they can resist the Gadhafi forces that have been advancing on rebel-held cities. Gadhafi's forces are "well-funded, well-equipped, and well-trained," Rabasa said, and that makes it difficult for the coalition to defeat them. "The Libyan people are tired of Gadhafi and the Libyan people are tired of Gadhafi," he said, and that's why he's calling on the international community to arm the rebels.

– NATO has taken the lead in striking at Moammar Gadhafi's forces in Libya, with the US providing the air cover, CNN reports. The North Atlantic Council, meeting in Brussels, approved a plan that will see NATO take control of the military mission in two to three days. NATO Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen said the North Atlantic Council had decided that "we are there to protect civilians... and that will be our focus." Meanwhile, anti-Gadhafi rebels say they've taken control of Ras Lanuf and Brega, two key cities that have been the targets of coalition airstrikes. Eight people were killed and 22 injured in Misrata, where a woman yesterday said she had been raped by Gadhafi's forces for two days, according to CNN.

– With Moammar Gadhafi seemingly losing control of Libya, the US is considering supplying arms to the rebels trying to oust him, CNN reports. British Prime Minister David Cameron and President Obama have discussed the idea, but the White House has yet to make a decision. Here's what you need to know: Gadhafi's forces continued their assault on Misrata today, with tanks moving in from the east and artillery from Moammar Gadhafi's arsenal falling into the hands of the rebels, the New York Times reports. Misrata's mayor, a Gadhafi loyalist, is dead, and more than 100 are wounded. Rebels say they've received no weapons from Gadhafi so far, but they'd need to get their hands on advanced weapons from Hezbollah or al-Qaeda if they want to defeat Gadhafi's forces. Gadhafi's forces have also bombed the oil port of Ras Lanuf, in an apparent attempt to cut off supplies, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– British diplomats are on the ground in Libya meeting with key figures of the opposition, but no decision has been made by Western allies on whether to arm them, the UK Foreign Office said today. British diplomats were on the ground in Libya meeting with key figures of the opposition, but no decision has been made by Western allies on whether to arm them, the UK Foreign Office said today. Meanwhile, NATO is investigating reports that rebels were killed in an airstrike, CNN reports.

– The top US commander in Libya told Congress today that the country’s “power struggle is stalemated, and is likely to remain that way on the basis of the current level of NATO commitment,” CNN reports. Gen. Carter Ham’s testimony comes on the heels of Bill Clinton’s call yesterday for Moammar Gadhafi to step down, and on the heels of a rebel commander’s claim that Gadhafi’s forces have killed more than 200 of their own people in the past 24 hours.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi launched a fresh attack on the rebel-held city of Misrata today, firing rockets into the air and setting houses on fire. At least five people were killed and 20 wounded, witnesses tell CNN. Gadhafi’s forces are also believed to be shelling the town of Jedaim. The attack comes a day after the US rejected a cease-fire proposed by the African Union.

– The ship carrying the bodies of American photojournalist Chris Hondros and British journalist Tim Hetherington, who were killed in Libya this week, arrived in Benghazi last night, CNN reports. The third chartered ship to arrive in the city is carrying the bodies of two other journalists who were killed in Misrata. Click here for more.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi launched an attack on the city of Misrata today, driving out residents and flattening buildings, witnesses tell CNN. Misrata has been cut off from the rest of the country by the Libyan strongman's forces, who have also launched attacks on the oil port of Ras Lanuf. “They took Misrata, they took Ras Lanuf, and now they are taking Misrata,” a resident tells the New York Times. “They are taking people out of the city. They are taking everything they can from the city. The electricity is out, the water is running low, and there are people dying every day. It’s just hell.”

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces shelled the rebel-held city of Misrata today, leaving many dead and wounded, a rebel spokesman tells CNN. “The shelling started at dawn and lasted for several hours,” he said, adding that Gadhafi’s forces are still shelling the western part of the city. Rebels have been trying to take Misrata for weeks, but have been unable to do so because of the NATO bombing campaign. Gadhafi’s forces have also been shelling the town of Jedaim, about 30 miles west of Misrata, according to another rebel spokesman.

– A voice believed to be that of Moammar Gadhafi has been broadcast on Libyan TV for the first time since he was last seen April 30, reports CNN. The voice on the state-run Libyan TV channel said that Gadhafi is alive and is in a place “where you can not kill me,” according to al-Jazeera.

– Moammar Gadhafi's forces are raping women at checkpoints and using sexual enhancement drugs as weapons, according to the chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court. The report comes as Libyan rebels praised President Obama's speech today on the US role in the Middle East, while some Syrian activists expressed disappointment that Obama did not push harder on their embattled ruler, reports CNN. In Benghazi, the heart of the Libyan revolt against longtime strongman Gadhafi, a rebel leader pronounced Obama's speech in support of democratic movements across the region—"good enough."

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces launched a major offensive against the western Libyan town of Zintan today, striking deep in the town’s center and setting houses on fire, a rebel commander tells CNN. Rebels are also battling Gadhafi’s loyalists in the nearby town of Jedaim. “They are trying to take the town of Jedaim from the rebels,” the commander says. Gadhafi’s forces have also launched attacks on the oil port of Ras Lanuf and on Gadhafi’s compound in Tripoli, the commander says, according to the Telegraph.

– NATO launched more than a dozen airstrikes on Tripoli early today, targeting the compound of Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi's Bab al-Aziziya, CNN reports. Smoke could be seen rising from the area near Gadhafi's Bab al-Azizia compound. NATO also attacked Gadhafi's inner city stronghold of Sirte, pummeling buildings there with more than a dozen airstrikes. The strikes were aimed at undermining Gadhafi's air defenses and targeting the leader's command and control infrastructure, according to the New York Times. NATO also attacked Gadhafi's inner city stronghold of Sirte, pummeling buildings there with more than a dozen airstrikes. The strikes were aimed at undermining Gadhafi's air defenses and targeting the leader's command and control infrastructure, according to the Times. NATO also attacked Gadhafi's inner city stronghold of Sirte, pummeling buildings there with more than a dozen airstrikes. The strikes were aimed at undermining Gadhafi's air defenses and targeting the leader's command and control infrastructure, according to the Times. The strikes were one of the heaviest NATO attacks on Tripoli so far.

– Russian President Dmitry Medvedev has joined the calls for Moammar Gadhafi to step down, CNN reports. “I think it is time for Gadhafi to leave,” Medvedev said, according to the Telegraph. “It is time for the Libyan people to have a government that represents them.” The US, meanwhile, is providing arms to the Libyan rebels.

– Looks like Moammar Gadhafi's days are numbered. Libya's oil minister has defected, CNN reports, along with eight generals. "I am with the Libyan people, with the Libyan people, against Gadhafi," said Abdel Fattah Younis, who had been in charge of the country's largest oil refinery. "I am with the Libyan people, with the Libyan people, against Gadhafi," he said, according to al-Jazeera. "I am with the Libyan people, with the Libyan people, against NATO." Younis is the highest-ranking defector so far. Click for more.

– As NATO continues to pound Moammar Gadhafi's compound in Tripoli, the Libyan leader has vowed not to surrender, CNN reports. "We will not give up," he said in a speech broadcast on state TV. "Dead, alive, victorious, it doesn't matter. We will stay until the end." At least 31 people have been killed in NATO airstrikes so far, including civilians.

– As NATO continues to pound Moammar Gadhafi’s forces in Libya, the US is considering arming the new transitional Libyan government, American officials tell the Wall Street Journal. Hillary Clinton is expected to raise the issue with NATO chief Anders Fogh Rasmussen at a meeting in Brussels today. “It’s something we’re looking at,” one official says. “We’re not ruling it out.” Meanwhile, a NATO official tells CNN that NATO doesn’t believe the UN resolution justifies killing Gadhafi. “We are simply not targeting individuals,” the official says.

– Libyan rebels say they’ve found videos on captured Gadhafi soldiers showing the regime’s henchmen raping women and torturing people, CNN reports. The videos have been erased from evidence, a rebel commander says, because “the stigma of rape is too great.” The New York Times, Washington Post, and New York Daily News have all editorialized harshly about NATO’s failure to intervene against Moammar Gadhafi.

– A NATO airstrike on a rebel-held town killed at least 12 people, including three children, yesterday, according to the Libyan government, which blamed NATO and the US for the deaths. The strike hit a home in Dafniya, a town west of Misrata, CNN reports. "NATO regrets the loss of innocent lives," a NATO spokesman said. "This was a precision strike on a legitimate military target." Three rockets fired by Moammar Gadhafi's forces hit a home in the town, killing a 14-year-old boy and his father, according to the Libyan government. "I found this place was on fire," said the boy's uncle, who rushed to the house when he heard the blast.

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi's grip on power appears to be loosening, as evidenced by the defection of the country's national soccer team to the rebels. Gadhafi's grip on power appears to be loosening, as evidenced by the defection of the country's national soccer team to the rebels. "Yes, that is what a doctor says to a patient request that is not in their best interest," he says.

– Michael Jackson's former doctor testified yesterday that the King of Pop was a frequent user of the prescription drug Propofol before he was jailed for child molestation. Dr. Robert Waldman, who treated Jackson from 2001 to 2003, told the Conrad Murray trial that the pop star was a frequent user of the drug, which is used to treat insomnia, as well as Ambien, Valium, and Xanax, the Daily Mail reports. Jackson's ex-wife, La Toya Jackson, testified that she was with the singer when he was arrested for child molestation in 2002, and that she told police that he had been using Propofol and other drugs. Dr. Waldman said that when Jackson was arrested for child molestation, he told police that he had been using the drug to treat his insomnia.

– The trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, who is accused of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, is expected to wrap up in a couple of weeks. Murray's attorneys tried to portray him as a naive, untrained doctor who gave Jackson a lethal dose of a powerful painkiller in an effort to wean him off it, but prosecutors painted a picture of a doctor who was more concerned with protecting Jackson's reputation than his patients. The Los Angeles Times has a profile of Murray here.

– Dr. Conrad Murray was found guilty today of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, reports the BBC. Jurors found that Murray gave Jackson a lethal dose of the surgical anesthetic Propofol in an effort to get him to sleep, then tried to mask the fact that he was in such bad shape that he wasn't using the drug. The Los Angeles County coroner's office ruled Jackson's death a homicide, saying he died after taking a lethal dose of the drug. Murray maintained that he had given Jackson only a small dose of the drug in an effort to wean him off it. He will be sentenced Nov. 29.

– Michael Jackson's death was no accident, according to Dr. Conrad Murray, who told Channel 4 in an interview that aired last night that he was trying to wean Jackson off the drug propofol before his death. "I was trying to wean him off this drug," he said. "I gave him a lethal dose of this drug, and I gave him the rest of his life." Murray, who was convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the death of the King of Pop, said he was trying to wean Jackson off the drug when he gave him the fatal dose. The full interview is here.

– The doctor convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson is due to be sentenced today, and if prosecutors have their way, Conrad Murray will spend the next four years in prison. The maximum sentence allowed by California law is four years, but Murray's lawyers have asked the judge to keep him on probation, saying he is already serving a lifetime sentence of self-punishment, the Los Angeles Times reports. Murray's defense team has argued that he was trying to wean himself off the powerful anesthesia that caused Jackson's death, but prosecutors have countered that the doctor gave the King of Pop a fatal overdose in an effort to wean him off the drug.

– The UN Security Council is set to vote tomorrow on a resolution demanding that Syrian President Bashar al-Assad step down, but Russia is threatening to veto it if it comes to a vote, diplomats tell the BBC. Russia's deputy foreign minister said today that his country could not support the draft because of changes made to it, but that Moscow needs more time to consider the changes.

– Russia's foreign minister arrived in Syria today for talks with President Bashar al-Assad, after the country's double veto of a UN resolution condemning the regime's bloody crackdown on anti-government protesters. The meeting between Sergei Lavrov and Assad is the first high-level interaction between Russia and Syria since the uprisings in the country began, the New York Times reports. Lavrov is expected to call for an end to the violence and for Assad to step down, according to the BBC. China and Russia say the resolution, which would have condemned the violence and called on Assad to step down, was biased and not in line with Russia's interests.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the Baba Amr neighborhood of Homs today, in what appears to be an attempt to cut off the city from the rest of the country, reports al-Jazeera. It's not clear what's behind the attack, but it comes a day after government forces killed more than 100 in Homs, and a day after UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said the Arab League would revive its mission in the country.

– The death toll in Syria today rose to 60, including two prominent Western journalists who were killed in the besieged city of Homs. Sunday Times reporter Marie Colvin and French photographer Remi Ochlik were killed when a shell hit a makeshift media center in the Baba Amr neighborhood, the BBC reports. In other developments: The UN Security Council is set to hold an emergency meeting today to discuss the situation in Syria, the New York Times reports. The US, Britain, France, and Turkey are boycotting the meeting because of Syria's alleged violation of international law. The Friends of Syria group of 70 nations is trying to pressure Syria into a ceasefire and allow humanitarian access. Syrian opposition protesters clashed with police outside the meeting in Tunisia, the BBC reports.

– Syrian troops launched a ground assault on the Baba Amr neighborhood in the city of Homs today, in what is believed to be the first serious ground assault since the uprising began a year ago. The Free Syrian Army has left Baba Amr, the New York Times reports, but it's not clear whether they'll be able to make it out alive. The assault comes as the UN Security Council prepares to vote on a resolution that would focus on humanitarian aid for Syria, in the hope that both China and Russia will back it. Dozens have been killed in recent days in Homs.

– The UN's humanitarian chief visited the hard-hit Syrian city of Homs today and described the devastation there as "completely devastated," the BBC reports. Valerie Amos said that while "limited progress" has been made in getting aid to the people of Homs, "much more is needed." Opposition activists, meanwhile, angrily rejected calls for talks between the government and the opposition.

– Syrian security forces fired on hundreds of protesters today in the city of Daraa, in the sixth straight day of violence that has killed more than 200 people, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The violence comes a day after UN-Arab League envoy Kofi Annan met with Syrian opposition figures in Turkey, where hundreds of thousands of refugees are streaming into Turkey from Syria, the BBC reports. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 200 people have been killed in today's violence, including 60 who were killed in the Baba Amr district of Homs, where security forces have been carrying out a brutal crackdown on protests.

– Two car bombs exploded in the heart of Damascus today, shaking the Syrian capital just a day after the first anniversary of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad's rule, the BBC reports. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the blasts, which Syrian state TV blamed on "terrorists." No one was hurt in the explosions, and there were no reports of gunfire in the area. The uprising against Assad's rule began a year ago today, and today marks one year since the first protests against Assad's rule, according to al-Jazeera.

– Bashar al-Assad has accepted the Arab League's peace plan for Syria, but the Syrian president "must stop terrorism as well," according to state media. The plan calls for Syria to withdraw its troops and heavy weapons from cities, and allow peaceful demonstrations, al-Jazeera reports. Arab League leaders are meeting today in Baghdad to discuss the plan. At the summit, Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri Maliki warned that a proxy war between Iraq and Syria could lead to civil war, the BBC reports.

– UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has condemned the Syrian government's renewed shelling of Homs and other violence ahead of tomorrow's supposed ceasefire, the BBC reports. "I condemn in the strongest possible terms the use of heavy weapons by the Syrian armed forces on residential areas, including Homs, Latamneh, and Baba Amr," Ban said in a statement. "I call on all sides to stop the killing and the use of heavy weapons, and to allow humanitarian aid to reach those in need." The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 100 people were killed in the Hama suburb of Latamneh today, according to al-Jazeera. The UN says more than 2,300 Syrian refugees have fled into Turkey in the past day, by far the highest number in a single day.

– Kofi Annan told the UN Security Council today that he is "alarmed" by reports of an increase in violence despite the Syrian government's compliance with the peace plan, the BBC reports. The Syrian government is "in contravention of an internationally agreed peace plan," Ban Ki-moon said in a closed-door meeting of the Security Council. Annan is working to get the UN and the Syrian government to reach an agreement on how to handle the ongoing violence.

– Syria is now in a state of civil war, and the government has lost control of "large chunks" of cities, the head of peacekeeping for the UN and UN observer mission there told reporters today, according to the BBC. "We were confronted with angry crowds," he said, noting that monitors had been attacked in Haffa, a town near the Turkish border. "There is now a state of civil war in Syria, and the government has lost control of large chunks of cities," he said. France is calling on the UN Security Council to make Kofi Annan's peace plan for Syria mandatory, the BBC reports.

– A suicide bomber detonated his explosives at the entrance to Syria's central bank in the heart of Damascus today, killing at least four people and wounding dozens more, according to state-run TV. The explosion occurred in a busy part of the city, near the headquarters of President Bashar al-Assad's regime, the BBC reports. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which tracks violence, reported that government forces had launched an "all-out offensive" against rebels in the capital. Fighting has also been reported in other parts of the city.

– The Syrian military today deployed at the entrances to the southern city of Deraa in an apparent attempt to calm protests, after five civilians were killed in yesterday's violence. The military also opened fire on protesters in the nearby city of Khirbet Ghazaleh, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. At least one person was killed in that incident, according to al-Jazeera. Meanwhile, in Yemen, President Ali Abdullah Saleh met with defense force officials today in an apparent attempt to smooth over tensions following yesterday's violence, according to Reuters.

– The UN Security Council is set to hold an emergency meeting today to discuss Syria's bloody crackdown on protesters, reports al-Jazeera. All of the council members—the US, Britain, France, Russia, and China—plan to attend, according to the New York Times. The move comes after the death toll in Syria rose to at least 37 people yesterday. In the latest violence, Syrian security forces opened fire on hundreds of protesters in the city of Daraa. France called on Syria to open up to dialogue with the opposition, and Germany joined the calls for an end to the violence, notes Reuters.

– Tens of thousands of anti-government protesters took to the streets in Syria today, in the biggest challenge yet to the regime of President Bashar al-Assad, reports the New York Times. At least three people were killed as protesters took to the streets in the towns of Rankus and Khirbet Ghazaleh, both near the border with Turkey, and in the city of Daraa, where the first protests broke out two weeks ago. In the north, meanwhile, government forces fired on protesters in the town of Khirbet Ghazaleh, killing one and wounding several, according to al-Jazeera.

– A huge explosion hit a gas station in northern Syria today, killing at least 22 people and injuring dozens more, opposition groups said. The blast hit a gas station in the town of Ras al-Ain, close to the Turkish border, the AP reports. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said at least seven people were killed and dozens more injured in the explosion. Activists said the blast was caused by government forces trying to retake the town from rebels.

– Video has emerged of the bloodiest day yet in the Syria protests, as security forces and pro-regime militiamen opened fire on thousands of demonstrators. The videos, which can be seen here and here, are unverified, but they appear to show at least some of the casualties, according to the New York Times. At least 30 people were killed yesterday, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which estimates that more than 200 have been killed since the protests began a week ago. President Obama condemned the "outrageous use of force" by the Syrian government, but stopped short of calling for the resignation of President Bashar al-Assad, Reuters reports.

– American Airlines' first-quarter loss widened as the airline took a $900 million write-down on the value of some of its jets, reports the Wall Street Journal. The write-down is related to the declining value of its A319 and A320 jets, which are no longer fuel-efficient in an era of soaring jet fuel costs. The airline also took a $900 million write-down on the value of its option to buy Air France-KLM. American's first-quarter results were actually better than analysts' expectations, notes the Journal, which had predicted a loss of $77 million.

– China released its first comprehensive review of the country's demographics in a decade today, and the results aren't pretty. The country's population is rapidly aging, and experts have warned that China could face potentially disastrous social and economic problems as the population ages and the number of Chinese of working age shrinks, Reuters reports.

– Britain's royal family is back to business as usual today, with Prince William, Kate Middleton, and the rest of the royal family arriving at London's St. George's Chapel for the first time since the wedding. Wills, Kate, and the rest of the royal family were greeted by thousands of well-wishers as they entered the chapel for the first time today, the Telegraph reports. Prince Charles and wife Camilla, the only members of the royal family who haven't left their London home since the wedding, were also at the chapel for the first time today. Click for more on the royal wedding.

– Protests against the government of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad continued for a fifth day today, with thousands taking to the streets in cities across the country, including Damascus, where they burned Syrian flags and shouted anti-Assad slogans, the AP reports. In one of the largest demonstrations yet, protesters gathered outside the Syrian embassy in Athens, where they burned posters of Assad and his father, former President Hafez al-Assad, and shouted slogans such as "No to dialogue with terrorists." In the capital of Damascus, police fired warning shots into the air as protesters tried to march on the embassy, Reuters reports. At least one person was injured in the clashes.

– Moammar Gadhafi's whereabouts are unknown after a NATO airstrike near the town of Bin Jawad last night, but there's no sign of any major damage to buildings or human lives, the Telegraph reports. NATO says the strike was in response to a report that Gadhafi's forces had taken control of Bin Jawad, a town near the Tunisian border that has been the site of clashes between rebels and Gadhafi's forces. A NATO spokesman says the strike was in response to a report that Gadhafi's forces had taken control of the town. In other developments: Gadhafi's whereabouts are unknown after a NATO airstrike near the town of Bin Jawad last night, but there's no sign of any major damage to buildings or human lives, the Telegraph reports. NATO pounded planes Libyan government targets yesterday but stalemate in the rebel war to unseat Gadhafi has presented Western powers with a dilemma over whether to offer covert aid to the rebel cause. Kuwait, not Syria, to run for UN rights body: envoys

– Video game company Brewin Dolphin plans to open a branch in Bristol, England, to capitalize on the country's fast-growing e-commerce market, the Telegraph reports. The company, which makes games for the likes of Mortal Kombat and Call of Duty, has already opened a branch in Vancouver. "This is a great opportunity for us to grow our business in the UK," says the company's CEO. The company, which reported a loss of $6.3 million in the six months to March, says it plans to open as many as 20 stores across the country by the end of the year.

– The world's longest-serving member of the House of Representatives, Rep. Peter King, has announced his retirement from Congress. The New York Times reports that King, who has been in the position since 1983, will not seek re-election this year. He was first elected in 1983, and was re-elected in 1984. He has been a member of the House since 1999. King was first elected to the Senate in 1984, and was re-elected in 1999. He has been a member of the House since 1999.

– The London Metal Exchange has announced a plan to create its own clearing house, still at the feasibility stage. The move comes after the London Stock Exchange announced plans to create its own clearing house last week. Reuters notes that the London Metal Exchange is the world's third-largest derivatives exchange, behind CME Group and the New York Stock Exchange.

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad has ordered the evacuation of all foreign diplomats and their families from the capital of Damascus, according to the country's official news agency. The move comes after the International Criminal Court charged Assad with crimes against humanity for the violent crackdown against protesters, Reuters reports. "The government has ordered the evacuation of all foreign diplomats and their families from the city of Damascus," said a statement from the Syrian government. It said the move was in response to the ICC's decision.

– Syrian helicopters fired on pro-democracy protesters today, in the first reported use of air power to quell unrest in the three-month-old uprising, witnesses tell Reuters. At least four people were killed, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which puts the death toll at 28. President Bashar al-Assad's forces, meanwhile, continued their assault on Homs, opening fire on hundreds of protesters as they tried to march on the presidential palace, the AP reports. In the north of the country, meanwhile, Syrian troops opened fire on soldiers mutinying in the town of Rankus.

– Asian markets were mixed today, with Japan's Nikkei down 1.1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng off 0.8%, according to the AP. China's Shanghai Composite Index was down 1.2%. Elsewhere, Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index was down 1.2% and South Korea's Kospi Index fell 0.8%.

– Syria's foreign minister today blamed "terrorists" for a series of bombings in Damascus that killed at least 30 people and injured scores more, reports the Telegraph. Walid Moallem also accused the US and its allies of involvement in the attacks, which he said were timed to coincide with the US-led invasion of Iraq. The attacks come a day after a blast in central Damascus killed at least 11 people and injured dozens more. The Syrian government has blamed the blasts on the al-Qaeda-linked al-Nusra Front, which has claimed responsibility for several other bombings.

– British PM David Cameron has apologized for his country's decision to allow an openly gay man to serve in the military, saying he was "deeply sorry" for offending those who served in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Telegraph reports. "I am deeply sorry that I have offended anyone who served in the armed forces or their families," Cameron said in a statement. "I am also deeply sorry that the decision has been made to allow a person who has served our country with honor and distinction to serve in the military." Britain allowed 24-year-old Mark Webber to serve in the military last year after he was convicted of homosexuality.

– The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting today to discuss the situation in Syria, where a violent crackdown has killed hundreds of people over the last two weeks, reports the New York Times. Syria's ambassador to the UN in New York has warned that the Security Council will be "worse off" if it doesn't take action against the regime. Russia, a longtime ally of Syria's Bashar al-Assad, has voiced support for the regime and warned that it will be "left behind by history" if it continues to back it.

– A huge anti-government protest took place in Syria today, with tens of thousands taking to the streets in the first major demonstration since the uprising began three months ago. The main protest was in the city of Daraa, which has been the epicenter of the uprising, the AP reports. Protesters marched on the presidential palace, calling for the resignation of President Bashar al-Assad, who has refused to step down since the uprising began. "We will not leave Daraa until he leaves, because he is responsible for all the deaths in the country," one protest organizer told al-Jazeera.

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi has warned that he will fight to the death to protect his country from Western intervention, reports the Telegraph. "I will fight to the death to protect Libya from the crusaders," he said in a televised address. "We will fight until the last man, until the last woman, until the last bullet, until we win." Gadhafi's statement is the first time he has made such a threat since the conflict began, notes the New York Times. NATO, meanwhile, is stepping up its bombing of Gadhafi's forces.

– The leader of Yemen's main opposition party was shot dead today as he left a mosque in the port city of Aden, al-Jazeera reports. Essam el-Erian, leader of the Yemeni National Council, was shot in the head as he left a mosque this morning, the AP reports. He was reportedly hit by a sniper's bullet as he tried to leave the mosque. A security official tells Reuters that el-Erian was killed by a sniper's bullet while trying to leave the mosque.

– A huge explosion rocked Yemen's main port city of Aden today, leveling buildings and sending a huge plume of smoke into the air, but no injuries were reported. It was the biggest blast to hit the country since President Ali Abdullah Saleh was deposed in a popular uprising last year. Yemen has been wracked by violence since the uprisings, with more than 200 people killed since March. The country's president-elect, Abed Rabbo Mansour al-Hadi, said the blast was caused by a bomb hidden in a parked car, the AP reports.

– Japan has become the world's first country to import more liquefied natural gas than it exports in a single month. In June, Japan set a record for the second month in a row, importing 46.7 million tons of the gas, up 14.5% from the previous month, the government said today. The gas is used to power the country's nuclear power plants and is in high demand as the country seeks to reduce its dependence on fossil fuels, the Wall Street Journal reports. Last month, Japan set a record for the second month in a row, importing 46.7 million tons of the gas, up 14.5% from the previous month, the government said today. The gas is used to power the country's nuclear power plants and is in high demand as the country seeks to reduce its dependence on fossil fuels, the Journal reports.

– A 14-year-old boy who shot and wounded a fellow student at a California high school before killing himself has been arrested and charged with attempted murder, the Los Angeles Times reports. Police say the teen shot and wounded 15-year-old Trinity Heber inside a classroom at Long Beach's EO Smith High School on Monday. Heber, a student at the school, was in the classroom but not harmed in the shooting. Heber's 16-year-old friend, a fellow student at the school, also was in the classroom but not injured in the shooting.

– The Mexican peso hit an all-time low against the US dollar in early trading today after the Mexican government announced that it would allow drug cartels to import up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexico, the AP reports. The government said in a statement that it would allow drug traffickers to buy up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexican pharmacies, which would then distribute the drug to drug-producing drug cartels in Mexico and Central America. "The government has decided to allow drug traffickers to buy up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexican pharmacies," said President Felipe Calderon in the statement. The Mexican government said it would allow drug traffickers to buy up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexican pharmacies, which would then distribute the drug to drug-producing drug cartels in Mexico and Central America.

– Libyan rebels said today they are in control of a key town that had been held by Gadhafi's regime, after launching a major offensive against the capital city of Tripoli. "We are in control of the town of Bir al-Ghanam and we are in control of all the roads leading to Tripoli," a spokesman for the National Transitional Council told Reuters. "We are in control of the town of Bir al-Ghanam and we are in control of all the roads leading to Tripoli," he said, adding that the town has been "liberated" from Gadhafi's forces. Tripoli has long been seen as a bastion of support for the Gadhafi regime, and the rebels are now in control of more than 60% of the city, according to the New York Times.

– The riots and looting that have rocked Britain over the last few days have been a far cry from the comparatively lighter demonstrations that have been a hallmark of anti-government protests in the country's cities over the last year. Riots broke out in London last night and spread to other parts of the country, with shops looted, cars torched, and people throwing rocks and bottles at police officers, reports the Guardian. "It's the most riots I've seen in my life," said one witness. "I've never seen anything like it before." In other Syria news: Human rights groups say at least 15 people have been killed as government forces continue their assault on the city of Homs, reports al-Jazeera. Click here for more.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the port city of Latakia today, in what was the third day of an assault on the northern city aimed at crushing protests against President Bashar al-Assad, witnesses and activists tell the Wall Street Journal. Latakia is the country's fourth-largest city and has long been an important source of income for Assad's regime, which has been trying to stamp out the protests since March. Today's shelling killed at least five people, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. In other developments: The UN's High Commissioner for Human Rights said the situation in Latakia is "very, very bad" and called for an immediate ceasefire, according to al-Jazeera.

– Syrian rebels seized an oil refinery on the main highway from Tripoli to Tunisia today as NATO jets bombed targets in the capital, reports Reuters. The rebels also took control of the town of Sabratha further west on the main highway. Meanwhile, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says the death toll in the 17-month-old uprising has risen to 3,600, including more than 100 civilians killed by artillery fire, according to al-Jazeera.

– Bashar al-Assad's regime is likely to face sanctions from the International Criminal Court if it continues its bloody crackdown on protesters, European Union foreign policy chief Catherine Ashton said today. The EU is working on sanctions of its own, possibly including an arms embargo and financial sanctions, she told reporters, according to the AP. The Syrian president is likely to face similar action from the ICC if he doesn't step down by the end of the year, she added. Ashton's comments came as the UN's human rights chief warned that the situation in Syria is getting worse by the day. At least 3,500 people have been killed in the crackdown, according to opposition groups.

– Tottenham Hotspur has signed Emmanuel Adebayor on a season-long loan from Manchester City, the English Premier League club announced today. The Togolese striker will join the club at the end of the season, the Telegraph reports. Bleacher Report has more on Adebayor here.

– Public sector chief executives should be forced to justify their salaries and have their pay docked if they fail to perform, according to a government-sponsored report released today. The report is designed to halt a decade-long trend that has seen pay at the top of the public sector grow faster than pay levels at the bottom, Reuters reports. Leading health charities boycotted the launch of the report, accusing ministers of failing to stand up to supermarkets and drinks companies.

– Forces loyal to Alassane Ouattara have launched a final assault on Laurent Gbagbo's bunker in the Ivory Coast capital of Abidjan, reports Reuters, in a bid to oust the country's outgoing president. "We are going to get him out of the bunker," said a spokesman for Ouattara's government. Gbagbo, who refused to sign a document recognizing Ouattara's election victory, is believed to still be holed up in the bunker.

– Wayne Rooney has lost his appeal against a two-match ban for swearing into a TV camera, meaning the Manchester United striker will miss the FA Cup semi-final against Manchester City on April 16 and the Premier League match against Fulham on Saturday, reports the Telegraph. Rooney was filmed swearing into a camera after United's 4-0 win at West Ham last weekend.

– The world's longest-serving member of the House of Representatives has announced that he will not seek re-election, reports the AP. Rep. Peter King said in a statement that he has decided not to seek re-election because he does not believe he has the votes to win. "I have concluded that I do not have the votes to win," he said. "I will not stand for re-election because I do not believe I have the votes to win."

– A huge explosion rocked Syria's second-largest city today, leveling buildings and sending at least one person to the hospital, according to opposition groups. The blast hit a residential area, but there were no reports of injuries, the AP reports. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says the blast hit a series of buildings in the city's Baba Amr district, including the central courthouse and the headquarters of the ruling party.

– Video has emerged of the bloodiest day yet in the Syria protests, as security forces and pro-regime militiamen opened fire on thousands of demonstrators. A NATO spokesman says the strike was in response to a report that Gadhafi's forces had taken control of the town. In other developments: Gadhafi's whereabouts are unknown after a NATO airstrike near the town of Bin Jawad last night, but there's no sign of any major damage to buildings or human lives, the Telegraph reports. – Egypt's prime minister has ordered the country's central bank to hold off on interest payments for at least a month to give the government time to pay its bills, the AP reports. Ahmed Shafiq said in a statement that the central bank's decision is in line with the government's request for time to pay its debts. The country's central bank has been struggling to pay its bills since the Arab Spring uprisings of the last two years. Shafiq said in the statement that the central bank's decision is in line with the government's request for time to pay its bills.

– The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting at noon today to address reports that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi has fled to Libya's borders, reports AP. If true, that would make Gadhafi the first leader to leave the country since Moammar Gadhafi took power in 2008. The Security Council hasn't been able to reach an agreement on how to deal with the crisis.

– Video game company Brewin Dolphin plans to open a branch in Bristol, England, to capitalize on the country's fast-growing e-commerce market, the Telegraph reports. The company, which makes games for the likes of Mortal Kombat and Call of Duty, has already opened a branch in Vancouver. "This is a great opportunity for us to grow our business in the UK," says the company's CEO. The company, which reported a loss of $6.3 million in the six months to March, says it plans to open as many as 20 stores across the country by the end of the year.

– The world's longest-serving member of the House of Representatives, Rep. Peter King, has announced his retirement from Congress. The New York Times reports that King, who has been in the position since 1983, will not seek re-election this year. He was first elected in 1983, and was re-elected in 1984. He has been a member of the House since 1999. King was first elected to the Senate in 1984, and was re-elected in 1999. He has been a member of the House since 1999.

– Protests over a fatal mining accident have been going on for nearly a week in China's Inner Mongolia, but things have calmed down after the government promised to improve safety. The unrest began after a herder was killed when he was hit by a coal truck in the region's biggest coal-producing region, the Telegraph reports. Hundreds of ethnic Mongolians took to the streets in the city of HOHHOT last week, protesting the death of the herder and the increasing number of miners in the area. Authorities have now promised to improve mining safety in the region.

– The London Metal Exchange has announced a plan to create its own clearing house, still at the feasibility stage. The move comes after the London Stock Exchange announced plans to create its own clearing house last week. Reuters notes that the London Metal Exchange is the world's third-largest derivatives exchange, behind CME Group and the New York Stock Exchange.

– The World Cup may be over, but that doesn't mean it's time to throw in the towel on Brazil's hopes of hosting the tournament for the first time in more than a century. President Dilma Rousseff has announced that she will not be seeking re-election and Rousseff's chief of staff, Dilma Rousseff's close friend and ally Michel Temer, has taken over, the BBC reports. Rousseff said in a statement that she had decided not to seek re-election because she does not believe she can effectively lead the country at this time. "I have decided not to seek re-election because I do not believe I can effectively lead the country at this time," she said. "I have also decided not to seek re-election because I do not believe I can effectively lead the country at this time."

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad has ordered the evacuation of all foreign diplomats and their families from the capital of Damascus, according to the country's official news agency. The move comes after the International Criminal Court charged Assad with crimes against humanity for the violent crackdown against protesters, Reuters reports. "The government has ordered the evacuation of all foreign diplomats and their families from the city of Damascus," said a statement from the Syrian government. It said the move was in response to the ICC's decision.

– Syrian helicopters fired on pro-democracy protesters today, in the first reported use of air power to quell unrest in the three-month-old uprising, witnesses tell Reuters. At least four people were killed, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which puts the death toll at 28. President Bashar al-Assad's forces, meanwhile, continued their assault on Homs, opening fire on hundreds of protesters as they tried to march on the presidential palace, the AP reports. In the north of the country, meanwhile, Syrian troops opened fire on soldiers mutinying in the town of Rankus.

– Asian markets were mixed today, with Japan's Nikkei down 1.1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng off 0.8%, according to the AP. China's Shanghai Composite Index was down 1.2%. Elsewhere, Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index was down 1.2% and South Korea's Kospi Index fell 0.8%.

– Syria's foreign minister today blamed "terrorists" for a series of bombings in Damascus that killed at least 30 people and injured scores more, reports the Telegraph. Walid Moallem also accused the US and its allies of involvement in the attacks, which he said were timed to coincide with the US-led invasion of Iraq. The attacks come a day after a blast in central Damascus killed at least 11 people and injured dozens more. The Syrian government has blamed the blasts on the al-Qaeda-linked al-Nusra Front, which has claimed responsibility for several other bombings.

– The US is on track to overtake Saudi Arabia as the world's biggest oil producer by the year's end, according to an analysis by the International Energy Agency. The Saudis currently hold about 40% of the world's oil production, but Saudi Arabia is expected to overtake them by the year's end. The IEA predicts that by the year's end, Saudi Arabia will hold 40% of the world's oil, up from the current 30%. – British PM David Cameron has apologized for his country's decision to allow an openly gay man to serve in the military, saying he was "deeply sorry" for offending those who served in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Telegraph reports. "I am deeply sorry that I have offended anyone who served in the armed forces or their families," Cameron said in a statement. "I am also deeply sorry that the decision has been made to allow a person who has served our country with honor and distinction to serve in the military." Britain allowed 24-year-old Mark Webber to serve in the military last year after he was convicted of homosexuality.

– The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting today to discuss the situation in Syria, where a violent crackdown has killed hundreds of people over the last two weeks, reports the New York Times. Syria's ambassador to the UN in New York has warned that the Security Council will be "worse off" if it doesn't take action against the regime. Russia, a longtime ally of Syria's Bashar al-Assad, has voiced support for the regime and warned that it will be "left behind by history" if it continues to back it.

– A huge anti-government protest took place in Syria today, with tens of thousands taking to the streets in the first major demonstration since the uprising began three months ago. The main protest was in the city of Daraa, which has been the epicenter of the uprising, the AP reports. Protesters marched on the presidential palace, calling for the resignation of President Bashar al-Assad, who has refused to step down since the uprising began. "We will not leave Daraa until he leaves, because he is responsible for all the deaths in the country," one protest organizer told al-Jazeera.

– Libyan rebels have seized a key town from Moammar Gadhafi's forces and are now in control of at least one other town, the Telegraph reports. The rebel stronghold of Jedaim is about 90 miles from Gadhafi's hometown of Sirte, and rebels say they have now taken the town's mayor, mayor's wife, and at least one policeman as hostages. "We have taken the town of Jedaim and are in control of at least one other town," a rebel spokesman said. "We are in control of the town of Kikla, which is about 90 miles away from Gadhafi's hometown of Sirte."

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi has warned that he will fight to the death to protect his country from Western intervention, reports the Telegraph. "I will fight to the death to protect Libya from the crusaders," he said in a televised address. "We will fight until the last man, until the last woman, until the last bullet, until we win." Gadhafi's statement is the first time he has made such a threat since the conflict began, notes the New York Times. NATO, meanwhile, is stepping up its bombing of Gadhafi's forces.

– The leader of Yemen's main opposition party was shot dead today as he left a mosque in the port city of Aden, al-Jazeera reports. Essam el-Erian, leader of the Yemeni National Council, was shot in the head as he left a mosque this morning, the AP reports. He was reportedly hit by a sniper's bullet as he tried to leave the mosque. A security official tells Reuters that el-Erian was killed by a sniper's bullet while trying to leave the mosque.

– A huge explosion rocked Yemen's main port city of Aden today, leveling buildings and sending a huge plume of smoke into the air, but no injuries were reported. It was the biggest blast to hit the country since President Ali Abdullah Saleh was deposed in a popular uprising last year. Yemen has been wracked by violence since the uprisings, with more than 200 people killed since March. The country's president-elect, Abed Rabbo Mansour al-Hadi, said the blast was caused by a bomb hidden in a parked car, the AP reports.

– Japan has become the world's first country to import more liquefied natural gas than it exports in a single month. In June, Japan set a record for the second month in a row, importing 46.7 million tons of the gas, up 14.5% from the previous month, the government said today. The gas is used to power the country's nuclear power plants and is in high demand as the country seeks to reduce its dependence on fossil fuels, the Wall Street Journal reports. Last month, Japan set a record for the second month in a row, importing 46.7 million tons of the gas, up 14.5% from the previous month, the government said today.
