– A 14-year-old boy who shot and wounded a fellow student at a California high school before killing himself has been arrested and charged with attempted murder, the Los Angeles Times reports. Police say the teen shot and wounded 15-year-old Trinity Heber inside a classroom at Long Beach's EO Smith High School on Monday. Heber, a student at the school, was in the classroom but not harmed in the shooting. Heber's 16-year-old friend, a fellow student at the school, also was in the classroom but not injured in the shooting.

– The Mexican peso hit an all-time low against the US dollar in early trading today after the Mexican government announced that it would allow drug cartels to import up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexico, the AP reports. The government said in a statement that it would allow drug traffickers to buy up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexican pharmacies, which would then distribute the drug to drug-producing drug cartels in Mexico and Central America. "The government has decided to allow drug traffickers to buy up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexican pharmacies," said President Felipe Calderon in the statement. The Mexican government said it would allow drug traffickers to buy up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexican pharmacies, which would then distribute the drug to drug-producing drug cartels in Mexico and Central America.

– Libyan rebels said today they are in control of a key town that had been held by Gadhafi's regime, after launching a major offensive against the capital city of Tripoli. "We are in control of the town of Bir al-Ghanam and we are in control of all the roads leading to Tripoli," a spokesman for the National Transitional Council told Reuters. "We are in control of the town of Bir al-Ghanam and we are in control of all the roads leading to Tripoli," he said, adding that the town has been "liberated" from Gadhafi's forces. Tripoli has long been seen as a bastion of support for the Gadhafi regime, and the rebels are now in control of more than 60% of the city, according to the New York Times.

– The riots and looting that have rocked Britain over the last few days have been a far cry from the comparatively lighter demonstrations that have been a hallmark of anti-government protests in the country's cities over the last year. Riots broke out in London last night and spread to other parts of the country, with shops looted, cars torched, and people throwing rocks and bottles at police officers, reports the Guardian. "It's the most riots I've seen in my life," said one witness. "I've never seen anything like it before." In other Syria news: Human rights groups say at least 15 people have been killed as government forces continue their assault on the city of Homs, reports al-Jazeera. Click here for more.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the port city of Latakia today, in what was the third day of an assault on the northern city aimed at crushing protests against President Bashar al-Assad, witnesses and activists tell the Wall Street Journal. Latakia is the country's fourth-largest city and has long been an important source of income for Assad's regime, which has been trying to stamp out the protests since March. Today's shelling killed at least five people, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. In other developments: The UN's High Commissioner for Human Rights said the situation in Latakia is "very, very bad" and called for an immediate ceasefire, according to al-Jazeera.

– Syrian rebels seized an oil refinery on the main highway from Tripoli to Tunisia today as NATO jets bombed targets in the capital, reports Reuters. The rebels also took control of the town of Sabratha further west on the main highway. Meanwhile, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says the death toll in the 17-month-old uprising has risen to 3,600, including more than 100 civilians killed by artillery fire, according to al-Jazeera.

– Bashar al-Assad's regime is likely to face sanctions from the International Criminal Court if it continues its bloody crackdown on protesters, European Union foreign policy chief Catherine Ashton said today. The EU is working on sanctions of its own, possibly including an arms embargo and financial sanctions, she told reporters, according to the AP. The Syrian president is likely to face similar action from the ICC if he doesn't step down by the end of the year, she added. Ashton's comments came as the UN's human rights chief warned that the situation in Syria is getting worse by the day. At least 3,500 people have been killed in the crackdown, according to opposition groups.

– Tottenham Hotspur has signed Emmanuel Adebayor on a season-long loan from Manchester City, the English Premier League club announced today. The Togolese striker will join the club at the end of the season, the Telegraph reports. Bleacher Report has more on Adebayor here.

– The stock market's rough summer isn't hurting Hargreaves Lansdown, a UK investment firm that says it has seen a huge jump in new business since the start of the summer, Reuters reports. The firm's founder says many of its clients, who lost money during the summer market volatility, have now decided to return to the business. "We've had a lot of people come in and say, 'I'm going to come back and invest in Hargreaves Lansdown,'" says the firm's chief executive. "They've lost a lot of money in the market and they want to get their money back."

– Egypt's new president, Mohamed Morsi, has been sworn in as the country's first freely elected leader in more than a decade, the country's state-run news agency reports. The election will be the first in which a freely elected leader will run the country, which has long been riven by political infighting and has been rocked by anti-government protests. "I will be the president of all Egyptians," said Morsi, who took office last month. "I will lead the country toward democracy and reform." The election is expected to be a landslide success.

– Moammar Gadhafi's son Saif al-Islam Gadhafi has been arrested and charged with crimes including murder and torture in connection with the death of his father, the Telegraph reports. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, who defected from the Libyan strongman's regime last year, was reportedly involved in the torture of detainees at Abu Ghraib prison. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi was also involved in the torture of detainees at Abu Ghraib, according to the Independent.

– The first shale gas well in the UK could be producing gas by mid-2013, according to the chief executive of a UK company. The company, Cuadrilla Resources, suspended exploration at the site last month after scientists detected tremors, but CEOrillarillarillarillarillarillarillarilla tells Reuters that the tremors were "extremely minor" and that the first gas well could be ready by mid-2013. He says the company has estimated the amount of shale gas in place at 200 trillion cubic feet, "the top end of what is estimated can be recovered from Europe's largest reserves in Poland."
– The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell about 100 points to close at 10,811 today. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also were down about 100 points.

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad is in hot water again, this time over allegations that he ordered the beheading of an American journalist. American journalist James Foley was killed in a helicopter crash over the weekend, and now Syrian officials say Assad himself ordered the killing, the New York Times reports. "I can confirm that there was a conversation between Mr. Assad and Mr. Foley," Syria's deputy foreign minister tells the Wall Street Journal. "I can confirm that there was a conversation between Mr. Foley and Mr. Assad."

– Britain's Royal Mint has released a commemorative coin to mark the upcoming wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, to be held at London's St. Paul's Cathedral on Oct. 27. The couple's eldest child, Prince George, will marry Kate's cousin, Pippa Middleton, on the day of the wedding.

– Nigeria's parliament has approved a budget that seeks to slash the country's costly fuel subsidies by a third, in a bid to boost infrastructure spending and create jobs, the AFP reports. The 2012 budget seeks to cut subsidies from the current $1.3 billion to $500 million by the end of the year. The budget also seeks to boost oil production from the current 2 million barrels a day to 3.5 million barrels a day by 2015, according to Reuters. The move to end the subsidies is likely to be unpopular with many Nigerians, who see them as the only benefit they gain from living in an oil-rich country.

– Syrian security forces opened fire on protesters today in the northern city of Aleppo, killing at least five, according to opposition groups. Aleppo is Syria's most populous city and has seen some of the worst violence as the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad's regime enters its seventh month. In other developments: Turkey is increasing pressure on Syria with border military exercises, economic sanctions, and the harboring of Syrian opposition groups and army defectors, but Ankara must tread carefully to avoid arousing the suspicion of Arab states or spurring Syrian counter-measures, reports Reuters. "War is only option to topple Syrian leader," says Turkey's deputy prime minister. "The only thing we can do is to prevent a civil war in Syria." The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting tomorrow to discuss the crisis in Syria.

– The chief executive of British telecom giant BT is stepping down effective immediately, the company announced today. Martin Sorrell will take over as CEO of the company, which has been struggling since the 2008 financial crisis. "I am very sad to announce that I will be leaving the company," Sorrell said in a statement. "This was a difficult decision to make, but I believe it is in the best interests of the company and its shareholders that I step down." Sorrell had been expected to take over as CEO of the company earlier this year.

– A video purporting to show the funeral of a pro-democracy protester shot dead by security forces in Syria is making the rounds, and it shows thousands of mourners in the streets of Deir al-Zour chanting for freedom, reports Reuters. The video, which could not be independently verified by Reuters, shows thousands of mourners on the streets chanting for freedom.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the Baba Amr district of Homs today, in the first major ground assault into the city since the uprising began seven months ago, witnesses and activists say. At least 25 people were killed, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. It's not clear whether the assault is linked to the Arab League's call for an end to the violence, but it comes as the UN's High Commissioner for Human Rights warns that the situation in the country is "on the verge of civil war," the AP reports.

– The death of Moammar Gadhafi has been followed by a wave of anti-government protests across the Middle East and North Africa. In Syria, protesters took to the streets after the news of Gadhafi's death broke, calling for President Bashar al-Assad's ouster and for the immediate release of all political prisoners, the Telegraph reports. In Yemen, meanwhile, security forces shot and killed at least 30 people as protesters took to the streets for the first time in the country's post-Gadhafi era, the AP reports.

– The White House has released the full text of President Obama's State of the Union address, which will be delivered at 9pm tonight. The full text is available at the White House's website here. The speech is expected to focus on the economy, and the Wall Street Journal predicts that Obama will call for an increase in the minimum wage from $7.25 to $10.10.

– NATO Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen said today that the alliance has no plans to intervene in Syria, but warned that Bashar al-Assad's regime must learn the lessons of Libya's civil war. "The regime must learn from the mistakes of the past," he said, according to Reuters. "It is time for the Syrian regime to begin the transition to a democratic, plural political system." Syria's foreign minister, Walid Moallem, responded by accusing NATO of interfering in his country's internal affairs and warned the alliance against any military intervention.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the rebellious city of Homs today, in what appears to be an attempt to put down a revolt against President Bashar al-Assad's rule. Activists tell Reuters that more than 30 people have been killed in the heaviest fighting in the city since the uprising began eight months ago. "They're trying to crush the resistance in the city," a human rights activist in Homs tells the New York Times. "They're trying to put an end to the uprising." In other developments: The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting tomorrow to discuss the violence, according to a draft resolution obtained by Reuters. The resolution calls for an immediate cessation of all violence and human rights abuses. It also demands that Syria allow journalists and human rights workers into the country.

– The Arab League suspended Syria today over the nation's continuing bloody crackdown on protesters, and Syria is not happy about it. The country's representative to the league, Walid Moallem, said the move showed that the League is "serving a Western and American agenda," reports the LA Times. The Syrian foreign ministry issued a statement saying that Moallem's statement was "incorrect and does not reflect the position of the Syrian government," reports al-Jazeera.

– France has recalled its ambassador to Syria after a series of attacks on the country's embassy in Damascus, including a suicide bombing last week that killed four people, the BBC reports. The embassy was attacked on the same day France's foreign minister said Bashar al-Assad's regime was on the brink of collapse. "It is clear that the situation in Syria is heading toward civil war," French Foreign Minister Alain Juppe said, according to Reuters.

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad told a German newspaper in an interview published last night that the country's bloody crackdown on protesters would continue, and that the Arab League's pressure would not work. "We will continue the crackdown in Syria and the Arab League's pressure will not succeed," he said, according to Deutsche Welle. "I don't think there will be a change in the behavior of the Syrian people." More than 5,000 people have been killed in Syria since the uprisings against Assad's rule began in March, according to Deutsche Welle, which notes that the death toll in Homs alone hit 60 yesterday.

– Libyan rebels say they've captured Moammar Gadhafi's son Saif al-Islam Gadhafi in a firefight near the town of Jedaim, Reuters reports. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi was taken into custody after the firefight, but it's not clear whether his father is among the rebels. Jedaim is about 30 miles south of Gadhafi's hometown of Sirte. The rebels say Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, who turned himself in yesterday, is the son of Gadhafi's former defense minister.

Cuomo, who declared a state of emergency in the counties of New York, Nassau, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Putnam, and Westchester, said in a statement that the state of emergency is necessary because of the "unprecedented scale and severity" of the storm. – The Syrian military today deployed at the entrances to the southern city of Deraa in an apparent attempt to calm protests, after five civilians were killed in yesterday's violence. The military also opened fire on protesters in the nearby city of Khirbet Ghazaleh, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. At least one person was killed in that incident, according to al-Jazeera. Meanwhile, in Yemen, President Ali Abdullah Saleh met with defense force officials today in an apparent attempt to smooth over tensions following yesterday's violence, according to Reuters.

– The UN Security Council is set to hold an emergency meeting today to discuss Syria's bloody crackdown on protesters, reports al-Jazeera. All of the council members—the US, Britain, France, Russia, and China—plan to attend, according to the New York Times. The move comes after the death toll in Syria rose to at least 37 people yesterday. In the latest violence, Syrian security forces opened fire on hundreds of protesters in the city of Daraa. France called on Syria to open up to dialogue with the opposition, and Germany joined the calls for an end to the violence, notes Reuters.

– Tens of thousands of anti-government protesters took to the streets in Syria today, in the biggest challenge yet to the regime of President Bashar al-Assad, reports the New York Times. At least three people were killed as protesters took to the streets in the towns of Rankus and Khirbet Ghazaleh, both near the border with Turkey, and in the city of Daraa, where the first protests broke out two weeks ago. In the north, meanwhile, government forces fired on protesters in the town of Khirbet Ghazaleh, killing one and wounding several, according to al-Jazeera.

– Ivory Coast strongman Laurent Gbagbo has refused to sign a document recognizing Alassane Ouattara's victory over him in the presidential election, Reuters reports. Gbagbo's spokesman says he will sign the document at a meeting with Ouattara's representatives today, but says he will not accept the results of the election. Gbagbo's refusal to sign the document means that Ouattara is now the country's legitimate leader, according to the New York Times. The Times notes that Gbagbo's refusal to sign the document means that he will likely be holed up in his home for the rest of his life.

– Japan's top court has ordered the government to explain why it has failed to curb sexual harassment in the workplace, in a ruling that could have implications for the country's closely watched labor market. – Manchester United's star-studded line-up for Sunday's Premier League game against West Bromwich Albion didn't exactly wow the crowd at Etihad Stadium, but the team managed to hold on to win 4-3. United's Robin van Persie scored the game-tying goal with a minute left in the game. (Video here.)
– The NBA's Atlanta Hawks are taking on the Indiana Pacers in the first game of a first-round playoff series on Friday night. The game will be broadcast live on TNT at 9pm Eastern.

– Russia's Interfax news agency is reporting that the country's armed forces have shot down a Russian warplane near the border with Ukraine, in what is believed to be the first time a Russian plane has been shot down over Ukraine. Interfax cites an anonymous military source as saying the plane was shot down near the town of Slovyansk. Ukraine's Defense Ministry says the plane was shot down by a surface-to-air missile.

– The world's longest-serving member of the House of Representatives has announced that he will not seek re-election, reports the AP. Rep. Peter King said in a statement that he has decided not to seek re-election because he does not believe he has the votes to win. "I have concluded that I do not have the votes to win," he said. "I will not stand for re-election because I do not believe I have the votes to win."

– A huge explosion rocked Syria's second-largest city today, leveling buildings and sending at least one person to the hospital, according to opposition groups. The blast hit a residential area, but there were no reports of injuries, the AP reports. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says the blast hit a series of buildings in the city's Baba Amr district, including the central courthouse and the headquarters of the ruling party.

– Syrian security forces opened fire on hundreds of protesters today, in what appears to be the bloodiest day yet in the eight-month uprising, according to an unconfirmed video picked up by al-Jazeera. At least 30 people were killed, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which says more than 3,000 have been injured. The footage comes after President Obama condemned the "outrageous use of force" by the government of Bashar al-Assad, notes Reuters.

– The price of a barrel of crude oil hit a record high of $97.59 yesterday, and analysts expect it to keep rising as the European Union considers sanctions against Syria, the Wall Street Journal reports. Syria exports only a small amount of oil, analysts say, and the quality is low. If sanctions hit Syria hard, world oil prices could rise yet further, although the physical market impact is very small, analysts say.

– Prince William and Kate Middleton will say "I do" today in front of hundreds of thousands of well-wishers at London's Westminster Abbey, in a ceremony that will be broadcast around the world. The newlyweds will wed at St. George's Chapel, the same place where their mother, Queen Elizabeth II, wed Prince Philip in 1953, the Telegraph reports. The ceremony will be followed by a reception at Windsor Castle, where guests will be able to watch the newlyweds dance the night away in a huge tent. Click for more on the royal wedding.

– Britain's royal family is back to business as usual today, with Prince William, Kate Middleton, and the rest of the royal family arriving at London's St. George's Chapel for the first time since the wedding. Wills, Kate, and the rest of the royal family were greeted by thousands of well-wishers as they entered the chapel for the first time today, the Telegraph reports. Prince Charles and wife Camilla, the only members of the royal family who haven't left their London home since the wedding, were also at the chapel for the first time today. Click for more on the royal wedding.

– Protests against the government of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad continued for a fifth day today, with thousands taking to the streets in cities across the country, including Damascus, where they burned Syrian flags and shouted anti-Assad slogans, the AP reports. In one of the largest demonstrations yet, protesters gathered outside the Syrian embassy in Athens, where they burned posters of Assad and his father, former President Hafez al-Assad, and shouted slogans such as "No to dialogue with terrorists." In the capital of Damascus, police fired warning shots into the air as protesters tried to march on the embassy, Reuters reports. At least one person was injured in the clashes.

– Kuwait has officially joined the UN Human Rights Council, a move that will make it the first Arab nation to sit on the body, the Wall Street Journal reports. The country's foreign minister made the announcement today, saying that Kuwait wanted to be part of the council "to protect human rights and fundamental freedoms" in the Middle East and Africa, according to al-Jazeera. Kuwait is currently a member of the Arab League.

– The US imposed sanctions on Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and other senior officials on Wednesday in a dramatic escalation of pressure on Syria to halt a violent crackdown on pro-democracy protests. The penalties include an asset freeze and travel ban on Assad, his inner circle, and several military and intelligence officials, the Wall Street Journal reports. The sanctions come as the US and other Western nations push Syria to end its bloody crackdown on protesters. In the latest crackdown, security forces fired on hundreds of demonstrators in the city of Latakia. Human rights groups say more than 1,000 people have been killed in the five-week crackdown, and more than 200 have been injured. The sanctions are a dramatic escalation of pressure on Syria to halt a violent crackdown on pro-democracy protests. The penalties include an asset freeze and travel ban on Assad, his inner circle, and several military and intelligence officials, the Journal reports. In the latest crackdown, security forces fired on hundreds of demonstrators in the city of Latakia. Human rights groups say more than 1,000 people have been killed in the five-week crackdown, and more than 200 have been injured.

– The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting at noon today to address reports that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi has fled to Libya's borders, reports AP. If true, that would make Gadhafi the first leader to leave the country since Moammar Gadhafi took power in 2008. The Security Council hasn't been able to reach an agreement on how to deal with the crisis.

– Video game company Brewin Dolphin plans to open a branch in Bristol, England, to capitalize on the country's fast-growing e-commerce market, the Telegraph reports. The company, which makes games for the likes of Mortal Kombat and Call of Duty, has already opened a branch in Vancouver. "This is a great opportunity for us to grow our business in the UK," says the company's CEO. The company, which reported a loss of $6.3 million in the six months to March, says it plans to open as many as 20 stores across the country by the end of the year.

– The world's longest-serving member of the House of Representatives, Rep. Peter King, has announced his retirement from Congress. The New York Times reports that King, who has been in the position since 1983, will not seek re-election this year. He was first elected in 1983, and was re-elected in 1984. He has been a member of the House since 1999. King was first elected to the Senate in 1984, and was re-elected in 1999. He has been a member of the House since 1999.

– Protests over a fatal accident involving a coal truck in China's Inner Mongolia have turned violent, with at least 20 people killed and hundreds more injured in clashes with police. The protests were sparked by the death of a herder killed when he was run over by a coal truck in the country's biggest coal-producing region, the Telegraph reports. Authorities say they will improve mining safety rules in the region, which has been rocked by protests for nearly a week.

– Brazil's lower house has voted to impeach President Dilma Rousseff in the wake of her alleged involvement in a money-laundering scandal, the AP reports. Rousseff is accused of conflicts of interest because she is a close ally of President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who was also allegedly involved in the money-laundering scandal.

– The World Cup may be over, but that doesn't mean it's time to throw in the towel on Brazil's hopes of hosting the tournament for the first time in more than a century. President Dilma Rousseff has announced that she will not be seeking re-election and Rousseff's chief of staff, Dilma Rousseff's close friend and ally Michel Temer, has taken over, the BBC reports. Rousseff said in a statement that she had decided not to seek re-election because she does not believe she can effectively lead the country at this time. "I have decided not to seek re-election because I do not believe I can effectively lead the country at this time," she said. "I have also decided not to seek re-election because I do not believe I can effectively lead the country at this time."

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad has ordered the evacuation of all foreign diplomats and their families from the capital of Damascus, according to the country's official news agency. The move comes after the International Criminal Court charged Assad with crimes against humanity for the violent crackdown against protesters, Reuters reports. "The government has ordered the evacuation of all foreign diplomats and their families from the city of Damascus," said a statement from the Syrian government. It said the move was in response to the ICC's decision.

– Syrian helicopters fired on pro-democracy protesters today, in the first reported use of air power to quell unrest in the three-month-old uprising, witnesses tell Reuters. At least four people were killed, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which puts the death toll at 28. President Bashar al-Assad's forces, meanwhile, continued their assault on Homs, opening fire on hundreds of protesters as they tried to march on the presidential palace, the AP reports. In the north of the country, meanwhile, Syrian troops opened fire on soldiers mutinying in the town of Rankus.

– Asian markets were mixed today, with Japan's Nikkei down 1.1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng off 0.8%, according to the AP. China's Shanghai Composite Index was down 1.2%. Elsewhere, Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index was down 1.2% and South Korea's Kospi Index fell 0.8%.

– Syria's foreign minister today blamed "terrorists" for a series of bombings in Damascus that killed at least 30 people and injured scores more, reports the Telegraph. Walid Moallem also accused the US and its allies of involvement in the attacks, which he said were timed to coincide with the US-led invasion of Iraq. The attacks come a day after a blast in central Damascus killed at least 11 people and injured dozens more. The Syrian government has blamed the blasts on the al-Qaeda-linked al-Nusra Front, which has claimed responsibility for several other bombings.

– The Supreme Court today struck down the Obama administration's ban on travelers from six Muslim-majority countries, a victory for the White House that could have implications for US policy in the region and around the world. The 5-4 decision came after the Justice Department argued that the ban violated the Constitution's ban on unreasonable search and seizure, reports the New York Times. The big question is whether the court will side with the White House in the future in similar cases, notes the Wall Street Journal.

– British PM David Cameron has apologized for his country's decision to allow an openly gay man to serve in the military, saying he was "deeply sorry" for offending many people, the Telegraph reports. "I am deeply sorry that I have offended many people," Cameron said in a speech in Prague, where he was visiting for the NATO summit. "I am also sorry that I have caused any offense." The gay man, 21-year-old Peter Downes, was allowed to serve in the military because his parents were British. "I am very sorry that I have offended so many people," Cameron said. "I am sorry that I have caused any offense."

– The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting today to discuss the situation in Syria, where a violent crackdown has killed hundreds of people over the last two weeks, reports the New York Times. Syria's ambassador to the UN in New York has warned that the Security Council will be "worse off" if it doesn't take action against the regime. Russia, a longtime ally of Syria's Bashar al-Assad, has voiced support for the regime and warned that it will be "left behind by history" if it continues to back it.

– A huge anti-government protest took place in Syria today, with tens of thousands taking to the streets in the first major demonstration since the uprising began three months ago. The main protest was in the city of Daraa, which has been the epicenter of the uprising, the AP reports. Protesters marched on the presidential palace, calling for the resignation of President Bashar al-Assad, who has refused to step down since the uprising began. "We will not leave Daraa until he leaves, because he is responsible for all the deaths in the country," one protest organizer told al-Jazeera.

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi has warned that he will fight to the death to protect his country from Western intervention, reports the Telegraph. "I will fight to the death to protect Libya from the crusaders," he said in a televised address. "We will fight until the last man, until the last woman, until the last bullet, until we win." Gadhafi's statement is the first time he has made such a threat since the conflict began, notes the New York Times. NATO, meanwhile, is stepping up its bombing of Gadhafi's forces.

– The leader of Yemen's main opposition party was shot dead today as he left a mosque in the port city of Aden, al-Jazeera reports. Essam el-Erian, leader of the Yemeni National Council, was shot in the head as he left a mosque this morning, the AP reports. He was reportedly hit by a sniper's bullet as he tried to leave the mosque. A security official tells Reuters that el-Erian was killed by a sniper's bullet while trying to leave the mosque.

– A huge explosion rocked Yemen's main port city of Aden today, leveling buildings and sending a huge plume of smoke into the air, but no injuries were reported. It was the biggest blast to hit the country since President Ali Abdullah Saleh was deposed in a popular uprising last year. Yemen has been wracked by violence since the uprisings, with more than 200 people killed since March. The country's president-elect, Abed Rabbo Mansour al-Hadi, said the blast was caused by a bomb hidden in a parked car, the AP reports.

– Japan has become the world's first country to import more liquefied natural gas than it exports in a single month. In June, Japan set a record for the second month in a row, importing 46.7 million tons of the gas, up 14.5% from the previous month, the government said today. The gas is used to power the country's nuclear power plants and is in high demand as the country seeks to reduce its dependence on fossil fuels, the Wall Street Journal reports. Last month, Japan set a record for the second month in a row, importing 46.7 million tons of the gas, up 14.5% from the previous month, the government said today. The gas is used to power the country's nuclear power plants and is in high demand as the country seeks to reduce its dependence on fossil fuels, the Journal reports.

– A 14-year-old boy who shot and wounded a fellow student at a California high school before killing himself has been arrested and charged with attempted murder, the Los Angeles Times reports. Police say the teen shot and wounded 15-year-old Trinity Heber inside a classroom at Long Beach's EO Smith High School on Monday. Heber, a student at the school, was in the classroom but not harmed in the shooting. Heber's 16-year-old friend, a fellow student at the school, also was in the classroom but not injured in the shooting.

– Europe's debt crisis is taking a heavy toll on the world's financial markets, which have been buoyed this week by a surprisingly strong jobs report in the US. Asian and European markets plunged today as investors worried about Greece's ability to repay its debt, while the euro hit a 3-month low against the dollar in early trading, reports the Wall Street Journal. Britain's FTSE 100 index of leading British stocks has fallen more than 1% this year as investors seek a safe haven from the euro zone's debt crisis and turmoil in the US, according to a Reuters poll.

– The Mexican peso hit an all-time low against the US dollar in early trading today after the Mexican government announced that it would allow drug cartels to import up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexico, the AP reports. The government said in a statement that it would allow drug traffickers to buy up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexican pharmacies, which would then distribute the drug to drug-producing drug cartels in Mexico and Central America. "The government has decided to allow drug traffickers to buy up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexican pharmacies," said President Felipe Calderon in the statement. The Mexican government said it would allow drug traffickers to buy up to 200,000 tons of marijuana from Mexican pharmacies, which would then distribute the drug to drug-producing drug cartels in Mexico and Central America.
– A video purports to show the aftermath of a Syrian airstrike that killed at least 140 people in the city of Latakia, according to Reuters.

– Libyan rebels said today they are in control of a key town that had been held by Gadhafi's regime, after launching a major offensive against the capital city of Tripoli. "We are in control of the town of Bir al-Ghanam and we are in control of all the roads leading to Tripoli," a spokesman for the National Transitional Council told Reuters. "We are in control of the town of Bir al-Ghanam and we are in control of all the roads leading to Tripoli," he said, adding that the town has been "liberated" from Gadhafi's forces. Tripoli has long been seen as a bastion of support for the Gadhafi regime, and the rebels are now in control of more than 60% of the city, according to the New York Times.

– The riots and looting that have rocked Britain over the last few days have been a far cry from the comparatively lighter demonstrations that have been a hallmark of anti-government protests in the country's cities over the last year. Riots broke out in London last night and spread to other parts of the country, with shops looted, cars torched, and people throwing rocks and bottles at police officers, reports the Guardian. "It's the most riots I've seen in my life," said one witness. "I've never seen anything like it before." In other Syria news: Human rights groups say at least 15 people have been killed as government forces continue their assault on the city of Homs, reports al-Jazeera. Click here for more.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the northern city of Latakia today, in the third day of a military assault aimed at crushing protests against President Bashar al-Assad, witnesses and activists tell Reuters. The city is a key ally of Assad's, and the assault has raised fears of a wider conflict in the country. In other developments: The UN's High Commissioner for Human Rights said today that the situation in Syria is "very, very alarming," the AP reports. He called on the government to stop the violence and allow journalists and human rights workers into the country. The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting tomorrow to discuss the situation.

– A German court has ordered the country's armed forces to stand down after a judge ruled that they had violated the country's labor laws by using excessive force on detainees, the Telegraph reports. The ruling by the lower court means that the country's armed forces will no longer be able to arrest people without warrants or search people's homes. The ruling follows a similar one by the country's supreme court earlier this month. The country's armed forces have been accused of using excessive force against detainees, including women and children, in the past.

– Syrian rebels seized an oil refinery on the main highway from Tripoli to Tunisia today, in their first major victory since the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad's regime began more than a year ago. The refinery in the city of Zawiyah is the country's largest, and analysts believe it could supply up to a third of Libya's oil needs, the Wall Street Journal reports. The rebels also took control of the town of Sabratha further west on the main highway. NATO, meanwhile, launched airstrikes on Tripoli in an attempt to cripple the regime's air defenses.

– Bashar al-Assad's regime is likely to face sanctions from the International Criminal Court if it continues its bloody crackdown on protesters, European Union foreign policy chief Catherine Ashton said today. The EU is working on sanctions of its own, possibly including an arms embargo and financial sanctions, she told reporters, according to the AP. The Syrian president is likely to face similar action from the ICC if he doesn't step down by the end of the year, she added. Ashton's comments came as the UN's human rights chief warned that the situation in Syria is getting worse by the day. At least 3,500 people have been killed in the crackdown, according to opposition groups.

– Tottenham Hotspur has signed Emmanuel Adebayor on a season-long loan from Manchester City, the English Premier League club announced today. The Togolese striker will join the club at the end of the season, the Telegraph reports. Bleacher Report has more on Adebayor here.

– The stock market's rough summer isn't hurting Hargreaves Lansdown, a UK investment firm that says it has seen a huge jump in new business since the start of the summer, Reuters reports. The firm's founder says many of its clients, who lost money during the summer market volatility, have now decided to return to the business. "We've had a lot of people come in and say, 'I'm going to come back and invest in Hargreaves Lansdown,'" says the firm's chief executive. "They've lost a lot of money in the market and they want to get their money back."

– A roadside bomb in northern Iraq has killed a police officer and injured at least five other people, authorities say. Police say the bomb was hidden in a wheelie bin near the town of Baiji, some 155 miles north of Baghdad, the AP reports.

– Egypt's new president, Mohamed Morsi, has been sworn in as the country's first freely elected leader in more than a decade, the country's state-run news agency reports. The election will be the first in which a freely elected leader will run the country, which has long been riven by political infighting and has been rocked by anti-government protests. "I will be the president of all Egyptians," said Morsi, who took office last month. "I will lead the country toward democracy and reform." The election is expected to be a landslide success.

– Moammar Gadhafi's son Saif al-Islam Gadhafi has been arrested and charged with crimes including murder and torture in connection with the death of his father, the Telegraph reports. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, who defected from the Libyan strongman's regime last year, was reportedly involved in the torture of detainees at Abu Ghraib prison. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi was also involved in the torture of detainees at Abu Ghraib, according to the Independent.

– AUCKLAND, Sept 17 (Reuters) – New Zealand Prime Minister John Key is calling for calm after a police officer shot and killed a man during a struggle in the city of Auckland on Saturday, the New Zealand Herald reports. Police say 31-year-old Brenton Atkinson shot and killed 28-year-old Brenton Atkinson outside a news conference where Key was expected to speak. Atkinson's body was found nearby a few hours later.

– The first shale gas well in the UK could be producing gas by mid-2013, according to the CEO of the company behind the well. CEOrilla Resources stopped drilling in the county of Lancashire earlier this month after seismic readings were found to be too high and low. But the tremors didn't stop Cuadrilla from trying to recover gas from the well, which it believes could contain 200 trillion cubic feet of natural gas, CEOrillarillarillarilla says. That's the top end of what is estimated to be the country's largest natural gas reserves, according to his company's estimate, which he says is based on the amount of shale gas in place, not the volume that could be recovered, Reuters reports. He says the first gas could be sold by mid-2013.

– If you're in a hospital that's offering free baby formula samples to patients, you may want to steer clear of the emergency room. A new report from the American Hospital Association finds that many hospitals are cutting back on the free samples, which have become a big money-maker for formula companies, the Wall Street Journal reports. According to the report, the number of hospitals offering the samples has fallen from 1,198 in 2007 to 977 in 2011. And while the number of hospitals offering the samples has fallen, the amount of money hospitals are spending on them has risen as well. In 2007, hospitals spent an average of $83 per baby per year on the free samples, according to the report, which notes that the number of hospitals offering the samples has fallen in recent years as the price of infant formula has risen.

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad is in hot water again, this time over allegations that he ordered the beheading of an American journalist. American journalist James Foley was killed in a helicopter crash over the weekend, and now Syrian officials say Assad himself ordered the killing, the New York Times reports. "I can confirm that there was a conversation between Mr. Assad and Mr. Foley," Syria's deputy foreign minister tells the Wall Street Journal. "I can confirm that there was a conversation between Mr. Foley and Mr. Assad."

– The chief executive of British telecom firm BT has resigned in the wake of a sex-abuse scandal that has engulfed the company, the BBC reports. Martin Sorrell, who joined the firm in 2007, said in a statement that he was "sorry for the distress this has caused" and that he had informed the company's board of his plans to step down. "I am deeply sorry for the distress this has caused the staff and customers of our company," he said. "I will do everything in my power to ensure that this does not happen again." Sorrell was accused of having an affair with a female employee while he was CEO of the company, which was bought by Verizon in 2009.

– Nigeria's parliament has approved a budget that seeks to slash the nation's costly fuel subsidies by a third, in a bid to boost spending on infrastructure and create jobs, the Guardian reports. The 2012 budget seeks to cut subsidies from the current $750 million to $350 million by the end of the fiscal year, which ends in March. The budget also seeks to boost oil production from the current 2 million barrels a day to 3.5 million barrels a day by 2015, according to Reuters.

– Syrian security forces opened fire on protesters today in the northern city of Aleppo, killing at least five, according to opposition groups. Aleppo is Syria's most populous city and has seen some of the worst violence as the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad's regime enters its seventh month. In other developments: Turkey is increasing pressure on Syria with border military exercises, economic sanctions, and the harboring of Syrian opposition groups and army defectors, but Ankara must tread carefully to avoid arousing the suspicion of Arab states or spurring Syrian counter-measures, reports Reuters. "War is only option to topple Syrian leader," says Turkey's deputy prime minister. "The only thing we can do is to prevent a civil war in Syria." The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting tomorrow to discuss the crisis in Syria.

– The chief executive of British telecom giant BT is stepping down effective immediately, the company announced today. Martin Sorrell will take over as CEO of the company, which has been struggling since the 2008 financial crisis. "I am very sad to announce that I will be leaving the company," Sorrell said in a statement. "This was a difficult decision to make, but I believe it is in the best interests of the company and its shareholders that I step down." Sorrell had been expected to take over as CEO of the company earlier this year.

– A video purporting to show the funeral of a pro-democracy protester shot dead by security forces in Syria is making the rounds, and it shows thousands of mourners in the streets of Deir al-Zour chanting for freedom, reports Reuters. The video, which could not be independently verified by Reuters, shows thousands of mourners on the streets chanting for freedom.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the Baba Amr district of Homs today, in the first major ground assault into the city since the uprising began seven months ago, witnesses and activists say. At least 25 people were killed, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. It's not clear whether the assault is linked to the Arab League's call for an end to the violence, but it comes as the UN's High Commissioner for Human Rights warns that the situation in the country is "on the verge of civil war," the AP reports.

– The death of Moammar Gadhafi has been followed by a wave of anti-government protests across the Middle East and North Africa. In Syria, protesters took to the streets after the news of Gadhafi's death broke, calling for President Bashar al-Assad's ouster and for the immediate release of all political prisoners, the Telegraph reports. In Yemen, meanwhile, security forces shot and killed at least 30 people as protesters took to the streets for the first time in the country's post-Gadhafi era, the AP reports.

– The White House has released the full text of President Obama's State of the Union address, which will be delivered at 9pm tonight. The full text is available at the White House's website here. The speech is expected to focus on the economy, and the Wall Street Journal predicts that Obama will call for an increase in the minimum wage from $7.25 to $10.10.

– The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant today for Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi on charges of crimes against humanity, reports the AP. The warrant accuses Gadhafi of crimes against humanity including torture and rape, and was issued by the court's chief prosecutor, Luis Moreno-Ocampo. Gadhafi has been holed up in his country's capital of Tripoli since last year, and his whereabouts are unknown.

– NATO Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen said today that the alliance has no plans to intervene in Syria, but warned that Bashar al-Assad's regime must learn the lessons of Libya's civil war. "The regime must learn from the mistakes of the past," he said, according to Reuters. "It is time for the Syrian regime to begin the transition to a democratic, plural political system." Syria's foreign minister, Walid Moallem, responded by accusing NATO of interfering in his country's internal affairs and warned the alliance against any military intervention.

– The World Cup may be over, but that doesn't mean it's time for Brazil to give up hope of hosting next year's tournament. President Dilma Rousseff says her government won't decide on a replacement for the tournament, which will be held in South Africa next year, until after consulting with the International Olympic Committee, reports the BBC.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the rebellious city of Homs today, in what appears to be an attempt to put down a revolt against President Bashar al-Assad's rule. Activists tell Reuters that more than 30 people have been killed in the heaviest fighting in the city since the uprising began eight months ago. "They're trying to crush the resistance in the city," a human rights activist in Homs tells the New York Times. "They're trying to put an end to the uprising." In other developments: The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting tomorrow to discuss the violence, according to a draft resolution obtained by Reuters. The resolution calls for an immediate cessation of all violence and human rights abuses. It also demands that Syria allow journalists and human rights workers into the country.

– The Arab League suspended Syria today over the nation's continuing bloody crackdown on protesters, and Syria is not happy about it. The country's representative to the league, Walid Moallem, said the move showed that the League is "serving a Western and American agenda," reports the LA Times. The Syrian foreign ministry issued a statement saying that Moallem's statement was "incorrect and does not reflect the position of the Syrian government," reports al-Jazeera.

– A video purporting to show the aftermath of yesterday's massacre of more than 100 people in the Syrian city of Latakia has gone viral on YouTube, reports Reuters. In the clip, a man is seen being dragged from a car by blood-splattered soldiers, and another man is seen running away from the scene. A human rights group says more than 200 people were killed in the attack, which it blames on security forces trying to crush the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad.

– Turkey is drawing up plans to create no-fly zones and buffer zones along its border with Syria to protect civilians if the Syrian crisis worsens, Turkish newspapers reported today. The move would be in response to reports that Syrian security forces have attacked civilians in the border province of Hatay, the Hurriyet Daily News reports. “If there is a big escalation in violence in Syria, Turkey will create no-fly zones and a buffer zone along its border with Syria,” the paper said, according to Reuters. “If there is a big escalation in violence in Syria, Turkey will create no-fly zones and a buffer zone along its border with Syria.”

– Bashar al-Assad told a British newspaper that Syria's bloody crackdown on protesters would continue, and that the Arab League's pressure on him to end it would not work. "The regime will not change its policy," he said in an interview with the Sunday Times, according to al-Jazeera. "The Arab League will not change its policy." The comments come as the death toll in the five-week-old uprising rose to more than 500, according to human rights groups. More than 200 people were killed yesterday, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Activists say more than 1,000 people have been killed in the crackdown.

– Kenneth Feinberg, the man in charge of payments to victims of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, says those who want to sue the oil giant over the disaster will have to give up that right. The administrator of the 9/11 victims' compensation fund, who has been criticized for taking too long to set up the program, says payments will be "more generous" than those offered by courts, the New York Times reports. "There will be no cap on the amount of money that can be paid," he said. "There will be no cap on the amount of time that it will take for the damage to be paid out."

– BP CEO Tony Hayward is taking more heat for taking time off to go sailing with his son—a trip the company initially said would have only a "very modest" impact on the Gulf oil spill. An internal document obtained by US Rep. Ed Markey shows that BP estimated that 100,000 barrels of oil a day could flow from the ruptured Gulf of Mexico well, nearly twice the current US estimate. That amount, included in an undated internal document released by Markey, is nearly twice the current US estimate of the leak, notes the BBC.

– The Coast Guard has shut down efforts to contain an oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico because of bad weather. The spill, caused by an explosion on a BP drilling rig, has now grown to about 1,500 square miles, the BBC reports. The Coast Guard says it is "very serious" about the environmental impact of the spill.

– The Coast Guard has deployed two ships to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. One of the ships will be a three-story, 110-foot-long containment box that BP hopes will help contain the spill. The other will be a remotely operated vehicle that will grab the oil and direct it to the surface of the sea. Meanwhile, BP is building a giant iron funnel to help contain the spill, the Telegraph reports.

– The Coast Guard has confirmed that oil is now washing ashore in Louisiana. It's the first confirmed spill in the state since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded last week, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. The Coast Guard is working with BP to contain the oil, which is at least 5,000 barrels a day—more than twice the amount previously thought to be leaking, the BBC reports. The spill is already the biggest in Louisiana's history, the Times-Picayune notes.

– BP chief Tony Hayward says his company is “absolutely responsible” for the massive oil spill off the Louisiana coast. “We have an armada of ships out there trying to clean it up,” he told the BBC. “We are responsible for the leak, we are responsible for the damage it will cause, and we will pay for the cleanup.” Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal, meanwhile, warned that the spill is threatening the way of life for people in his state and in three other states, the Telegraph reports.

– BP is considering using golf balls and tires as junk shots in an attempt to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Chief operating officer Doug Suttles said the so-called junk shot was one option after previous attempts to stem the flow failed, the Telegraph reports. Another option is to place a smaller containment box over the blown-out well, the Guardian reports.

– BP's latest attempt to contain oil in the Gulf of Mexico has been delayed for at least a few days, reports the Times-Picayune. The company had planned to lower a containment dome over the leak to slow the spread of oil, but it's not clear whether that will happen today or tomorrow. The US government, meanwhile, is demanding that BP clarify its commitment to pay spill costs, notes the BBC.

– The first oil from the Gulf spill has entered an ocean current that could take it to Florida and up the east coast of the US, scientists say. The Loop Current could carry the oil as far as Key West, Fla., and possibly as far as Jacksonville, Fla., the Los Angeles Times reports. If the oil washes up on Florida's beaches, it could be days before it's cleaned up, the New York Times notes. A Coast Guard official told Congress today that oil from the spill may reach the state's coast within a week, the BBC reports. Any oil that does wash up is likely to be in the form of tarballs, which are a little easier to manage, he said.

– BP's latest progress report on the Gulf oil spill contains some eye-popping numbers: It estimates 5,000 barrels a day are being siphoned from the well, but the US government says that's far too much. In a letter to BP, the government says the company "has fallen short" in providing real-time information on the spill, reports the New York Times. (Read the letter in full here.) It also notes that BP's estimate of 5,000 barrels a day is based on the company's estimation of the total amount of oil being released, not the amount beingsiphoned. BP says it will update the government's estimate of the amount of oil being released later today. Meanwhile, Greenpeace protesters unfurled a banner at BP's London headquarters today with the company's logo smudged in oil, but no arrests were made.

– The Obama administration has told BP to clean up its act in the wake of the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar said today that the feds will not let BP off the hook for cleanup costs until it plugs the well, reports the New York Times. "We're not going to let them off the hook," he said at a news conference with Gov. Bobby Jindal. "We're not going to let them off the hook until they stop the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico." Meanwhile, BP began sharing details of its internal investigation with the US government, notes the Telegraph.

– BP's latest plan to plug its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico is going according to plan, CEO Tony Hayward said today. The company will decide tomorrow whether to proceed with the so-called "top kill" plan, which involves pumping mud into the well in an effort to plug it, the BBC reports. "We have the best people working on this," Hayward said. "It's going to be a day-by-day process until we know what's going on."

– BP has failed in its latest attempt to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The company announced the failure of its so-called "top kill" procedure, which involves pumping mud into the gushing well in an effort to plug it. "We have been unable to overcome the flow," BP said in a statement. "We have been unable to overcome the flow." The news comes as the White House said the spill is the worst environmental disaster the US has faced, reports the Telegraph.

– The feds have launched a criminal investigation into the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Attorney General Eric Holder said today. Holder did not say which companies or individuals were being targeted, the BBC reports. Earlier, BP launched a new attempt to try to contain the spill using undersea robots to cut off the fractured pipe and seal it with a cap. The company's share price, meanwhile, fell 13% after falling at one stage to its lowest level in 15 months. BP says it will pay for the construction of six sand barriers off the coast of Louisiana to protect fragile wetlands from a huge oil slick.

– BP lowered a containment cap over the gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico today in what appears to be a success, reports the BBC. The company says it has so far managed to capture 10,000 barrels of oil a day, a figure that is about half of the estimated 12,000 to 19,000 barrels leaking daily. It's not clear how much oil is being captured, but the BBC notes that it will take a few days to know for sure.

– President Obama's blunt criticism of BP CEO Tony Hayward's handling of the Gulf oil spill continues to take a toll on the company's share price. Shares fell another 5% on the London Stock Exchange today, reports the BBC. In an interview with NBC's Meet the Press, Obama said Hayward's comments about wanting his life back and the "big ocean" in the Gulf were "beyond unacceptable." "The American people deserve to know that Tony Hayward did not know what he was talking about when he said, 'I want my life back, and the Gulf is—it's a big ocean.'"

– London Mayor Boris Johnson is worried about the “anti-British rhetoric that seems to be permeating from America” in the wake of the BP oil spill. “I would like to see a bit of cool heads rather than endlessly buck—passing and name—calling,” he said on BBC Radio 4’s Today program. “It’s not often that a US president has cause to declare that, given the chance, he would sack the boss of one of the UK’s leading companies,” Johnson continued. “And now surely it’s time for Mr. Cameron to tell some of these truths to President Obama, in defense of BP, a vital British company that has been systematically sabotaged by a petty and vengeful American government.”

– President Obama promised to make BP pay for the damage its oil spill has caused in his first Oval Office address to the nation. "We will make BP pay for the damage their company has caused," he said. "We will make BP set up a fund to pay for the damage their company has caused." Obama also promised that his administration would ramp up efforts to promote clean energy, reports the BBC. "We will protect the environment," he said. "And we will make sure that our energy security is as strong as it can be."

– Tony Hayward's testimony before a House panel today got off to a rocky start with Henry Waxman accusing the CEO of being "stonewalling" during his testimony. Waxman also accused BP of being "inattentive" to dangers at its drilling site, reports the BBC. When Hayward said he wanted his life back, Waxman responded, "That's not going to happen. That's not going to happen." Other lawmakers also got in on the act, with Democrat Tom Coburn calling Hayward's testimony a "cop-out," reports the Wall Street Journal. BP shares closed up 7% after the company agreed to set up a $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the Gulf oil spill.

– BP's share price has plunged since the oil disaster began, and the company's top bosses are due in Aberdeen to reassure staff the company has no plans to leave the North Sea. The company faces enormous costs for the Gulf of Mexico explosion, which left 11 people dead and caused a major leak. BP has said the cost of cleaning up the oil leak in the Gulf has now reached $ 2.65 billion. – BP removed the containment cap on its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico today after a robot sub bumped into the venting system, reports the BBC. The venting system was reattached to the venting system, but the company will need to install a new one before it can seal the well. The live video feed of BP's latest attempt to contain the oil is live, but it's not clear whether the company will be able to do so in a day or two.

– It looks like a ghost town around here. That's what Shrimper Randy Nunez had to say about his hometown of Hammond, La., after a police car pulled up next to him while he was eating breakfast at a restaurant, reports the Times-Picayune. "It looks like a ghost town around here," he said.

– tar balls from the Gulf oil spill have made their way to all five US Gulf states, the BBC reports. Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida have all seen some kind of oil wash up on their shores. It’s not clear whether the tar balls were carried on a ship or carried on a beach, but they have now hit all five states. Meanwhile, BP shares rose on speculation that Middle Eastern investors might buy a stake in the company, the Telegraph reports.

– The US government has given BP 24 hours to provide "detailed plans and timelines" on how it plans to stop the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Adm Thad Allen sent a letter to the oil giant's managing director saying the company must hand over plans and timelines on stopping the leak, the BBC reports. BP began drilling two relief wells in May BP says its operation to drill a relief well to stop the Gulf of Mexico oil leak is slightly ahead of schedule. A spokeswoman for the company told the BBC it was slightly ahead of the original schedule of completion in August. Meanwhile, one of BP's partners in the deepwater well that exploded in April has refused to pay its share of the costs so far.

– Underwater robots have removed a leaking cap on BP's Gulf of Mexico oil well, the first stage in fitting a tighter cap, the BBC reports. BP has been using undersea robots to fit the sealing cap, and Thad Allen, the US Coast Guard commander overseeing the spill response, says "significant progress" has been made. This could lead to the shutting of the well, he said.

– BP says it has stopped oil flowing into the Gulf of Mexico for the first time since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded in April. It's the first time the flow has been stopped since an explosion on the rig killed 11 workers, and President Obama said it was "important we don't get ahead of ourselves." The US official in charge of the spill clean-up, Thad Allen, said the " integrity test" would not stop until Sunday afternoon, reports the BBC. He said that when BP was ready to increase the pressure in the capping stack, he would do the same.

– Thad Allen, the US official in charge of the Gulf oil spill, warned today that BP may have to remove the cap on its damaged oil well. BP can keep the cap closed for another day, says Allen Admiral Paul Zukunft, US Coast Guard: "There is no new oil coming up at the source." Shares in BP have closed down nearly 5% in London amid uncertainty over the success of its latest attempts to stop the Gulf of Mexico oil leak. Earlier Thad Allen, the US official overseeing the oil clean—up, warned that BP may have to remove the cap on its damaged oil well. Allen said that if a substance leaking from the seabed was found to be methane, this might mean oil was also leaking. – BP will start drilling off the Libyan coast in the next few weeks, the company has confirmed. The deepwater drilling will take place in the Gulf of Sirte following a deal signed in 2007 with Libya on oil and gas development. The deepwater drilling will take place in the Gulf of Sirte following a deal signed in 2007 with Libya on oil and gas development. – The X Prize Foundation is offering $1.4 million to anyone who can come up with a better way to clean up the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. The clean-up challenge is the latest in the foundation's ongoing effort to come up with "radical breakthroughs" for the benefit of humanity, the Telegraph reports. The X Prize Foundation, best known for launching the private spaceflight industry, says it wants to replace "clumsy" and "c clumsy" methods used so far.

– The "static kill" procedure that BP hopes will permanently seal the Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico is scheduled to begin at 6pm local time, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. The live operation will involve pumping mud into the well, and Thad Allen, the US Coast Guard's official in the region, will oversee. The procedure is expected to last at least 24 hours, notes the BBC.

– BP has completed its "static kill" procedure and is ready to declare an end to the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, the New York Times reports. The procedure, which involved pumping mud into the top of the well, is expected to be done early next week. "We're ready to declare an end to the worst oil spill in US history," BP CEO Tony Hayward told reporters yesterday. "It's going to be a day-by-day process. It's going to take a couple of days to do it, but it's going to be done quickly."

– As BP works to permanently plug its blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico, it's also busy investigating several hundred claims for compensation from those whose livelihoods have been affected by the oil spill. The company has already paid out more than 300 claims for compensation from those whose livelihoods have been affected by the oil spill, according to a report in the New York Daily News. But that's not the only thing BP is busy with: It's also investigating several hundred claims for compensation from those whose livelihoods have been affected by the oil spill. The company has already paid out more than 300 claims for compensation from those whose livelihoods have been affected by the oil spill.

– In the wake of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the Obama administration has taken a hard look at its own response to the disaster. The White House has ordered a review of its response to the spill, which began in April, to make sure it's as effective as possible, the Wall Street Journal reports. Among other things, it's looking at whether the government could have done more to prevent the spill, and whether it could have done more to prevent the damage it did to the environment. The president's chief of staff, Denis McDonough, tells the Journal that the review will help the administration "make sure we're doing everything we possibly can to prevent future spills." – President Obama has signed an executive order designed to give federal agencies more authority to regulate the tobacco industry, the White House said in a statement. The order, which Congress is expected to approve later this week, gives the Commerce Department, the EPA, and the Office of Management and Budget the power to regulate tobacco production, sale, and use, as well as to grant tax-exempt status to companies that buy tobacco products, the White House said. The move is part of a broader effort by the Obama administration to reform the nation's struggling tobacco industry. "The executive order signed today will give the federal government even more power to regulate the tobacco industry," said White House spokesman Jay Carney. "It will also give the Office of Management and Budget the authority to grant tax-exempt status to companies that buy tobacco products."

– The cost of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill has risen by more than $2 billion in the last month alone, according to BP. The company says the cost of the spill has now hit a maximum of $8 billion, the BBC reports. BP says the cost of the spill has been rising quickly because the company has been unable to contain the oil, and because it has been unable to replace the blowout preventer at the site of the accident, the Guardian reports. BP says the cost of the spill has been rising quickly because the company has been unable to contain the oil, and because it has been unable to replace the blowout preventer at the site of the accident.
