The blowout preventer is being slowly raised to the surface BP has replaced a damanged blowout preventer that failed to stop oil from leaking into the Gulf of Mexico when a drilling rig exploded in April. The 300 ton device will be examined as part of the inquiry into the leak of 206 million gallons of oil into the Gulf.

– The Coast Guard says BP's final oil well in the Gulf of Mexico will be permanently sealed by Sunday afternoon. Adm Thad Allen says the well should be sealed within 96 hours, the Telegraph reports. BP chief Tony Hayward told British lawmakers that the Gulf oil spill was "devastating" to him and the company, and that the damage to the region's ecosystem was "as bad as any I have ever seen." The US government is also planning to require oil companies to plug 3,500 non-producing Gulf of Mexico oil wells in an effort to prevent future leaks, officials say. The Interior Department will also require companies to dismantle 650 unused oil and gas platforms. Louisiana fish deaths raise oil spill questions. The dead fish found at Bayou Chaland in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana, include pogies, redfish, drum, crabs, shrimp, and freshwater eel, officials say. Officials in Louisiana's Plaquemines Parish have called for an investigation after finding hundreds of thousands of dead fish near the Mississippi River. The Plaquemines Parish Inland Waterways Strike Force claims oil was spotted in pictures of the dead fish.

– Transocean, Halliburton, and Cameron are all to blame for the catastrophic explosion of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig, according to BP’s internal report. Transocean, the owner of the rig, called the report “self serving,” the Telegraph reports. BP’s internal investigation also found that the blowout preventer was not adequately maintained, the blowout preventer itself was not properly maintained, and the blowout preventer itself was not properly repaired after the explosion, according to the report. Transocean, Halliburton, and Cameron will all be named in the civil claims filed against them by victims of the oil spill.

– The Coast Guard says no oil appears to be leaking from a drilling rig that exploded and sank in the Gulf of Mexico, but officials are trying to contain what spilled after the blast and prevent any threat to the coast's fragile ecosystem. The Coast Guard says it is working to contain what spilled after the blast and prevent any threat to the coast, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports.

– The head of the company that owned the oil rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico says it was triggered by a bubble of methane gas that escaped from the well and shot up the rig, reports the Wall Street Journal. Mariner Energy's CEO says the blowout was caused by a failure of the cement in the pipe used to seal the well, notes the AP. BP, meanwhile, says it will pay "all necessary and appropriate clean-up costs" from the massive oil spill in the Gulf.

– Federal officials say they plan to investigate every possible cause of last week's massive explosion on the Deepwater Horizon oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico—including the possibility of criminal acts or negligence, reports Reuters. In the aftermath of the blast, an uncapped underwater oil well continues to leak an estimated 200,000 gallons of oil into the Gulf every day—creating a monstrous oil slick that made landfall in Louisiana's wetlands Thursday night and could become the nation's worst environmental disaster in decades. The Coast Guard has confirmed that 11 workers are still missing. Click here for more on the oil spill.

– BP's chief executive has resigned over the company's handling of the Gulf oil spill, reports the Wall Street Journal. Tony Hayward, who took over in August, will be replaced as CEO by Tony Hayward's successor, reports the New York Times, which notes that Hayward's ties to the company date back to his days as CEO of Transocean, BP's predecessor in the drilling business.

– The Coast Guard has taken over control of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New York Times reports. The Coast Guard took over the command from BP, which was responsible for the oil rig that exploded last week, because the two companies can't agree on how to divvy up the mess. “The Coast Guard is in charge of the cleanup,” said a Coast Guard spokesman. “We will be in charge of the cleanup from the ground up.”

– The Coast Guard says the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is at least five times larger than thought. The Coast Guard estimates 5,000 barrels a day of oil are leaking from the Deepwater Horizon rig, up from the previous estimate of 2,000 barrels a day. The spill is already threatening the fragile islands and barrier marshes of Louisiana, the Guardian reports. The spill is now moving toward Louisiana's fragile islands and barrier marshes.

– President Obama will fly to Louisiana today to see for himself the effects of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, the Times-Picayune reports. He'll be joined by Gov. Bobby Jindal, who has declared a state of emergency and is calling on the federal government to step up efforts to contain the spill. The president will also meet with local officials and tour a command center, the AP reports. Meanwhile, BP CEO Tony Hayward is on his way to Washington to face questions about the company's handling of the spill, the Guardian reports.

– The White House sent a phalanx of officials to the Gulf today to assure the public that no oil was leaking from the Deepwater Horizon rig, the Guardian reports. The administration also released a 6,000-word timeline of its efforts to contain the oil, and dispatched Thad Allen to the region. Meanwhile, BP announced that it had capped one of three leaks from the sunken rig, but said the work was unlikely to reduce the overall flow of oil into the Gulf. Click here for more.

– BP's latest plan to deal with the Gulf oil spill might involve shooting junk like golf balls and tires into the well. The idea is to lower mud into the well to plug it, but it's a long shot, the Telegraph reports. "It's a long shot, but it might just work," says one expert. BP chief Tony Hayward said the company is considering the "top kill" plan, in which heavy mud would be pumped in to plug the well. The junk shot is one of several ideas being considered for dealing with the spill, notes the Guardian.

– BP finally released video footage of the Gulf oil spill last night, and it’s a bleak one. In it, the Deepwater Horizon rig is visible in the distance, with oil visible all the way down to the surface. It’s the first underwater video footage of the spill, the New York Times reports, and it’s likely to intensify the pressure on BP CEO Tony Hayward to do something about it. Click here for more.

– Ocean scientists have discovered huge plumes of oil coagulating at up to 1,300 feet below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico, raising fears that the BP oil spill may be larger than thought and that it might create huge—and dead zones—of oil on the ocean floor, the Guardian reports. BP says it is working to contain the oil, which is still pouring into the Gulf at a rate of about 2,000 barrels a day, but scientists warn that the amount of oil leaking into the ocean is far higher than the company estimates. “This is very, very concerning,” says a marine ecologist. “It’s going to create a very, very large dead zone.”

– BP's latest attempt to contain the Gulf oil spill has been foiled by a live video shot of a "spillcam" that lives on the other side of the ocean, the Guardian reports. The video shot by a boat crew off the Louisiana coast shows what appears to be heavy oil coming up from the ocean floor. It's not clear whether the video is real, but it's drawing attention because it's being watched by the public. "It's a livecam that's on the other side of the ocean," says a spokesman for a marine environmental group. "It's a live shot of the oil coming up from the ocean, and it's not clear whether it's coming from BP or other companies." The video was shot on a boat owned by Transocean, BP's drilling partner, and it's one of many that BP has been shooting into the air in an attempt to show the damage the spill is doing to the ocean.

– BP CEO Tony Hayward has been forced to resign over the company's handling of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, the Wall Street Journal reports. Hayward, who had been in charge of overseeing the company's response to the spill, was "removed from his position effective immediately," BP said in a statement. "He has been with the company for four years and has been involved in day-to-day operations of the company for that length of time." He will be replaced as CEO by Bob Dudley, who had been in charge of the company's response to the spill. BP said in a statement that Hayward, who has been with the company since 2009, will be reassigned to an "other role."

– A live video feed of BP's latest attempt to plug the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is being watched around the world, but the company's chief executive says it will be at least a day before we know whether the "top kill" plan has worked. "It will be at least 24 hours before we know whether it has," Tony Hayward told reporters. "It's a day-to-day process. We're not going to know for sure until we know the results." The Washington Post reports that President Obama's reaction to the news of the spill has been leaked.

– Shares in BP plunged as much as 20% today in the wake of the company's failure to stop the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and CEO Tony Hayward's "I'd like my life back" gaffe. The slide wiped about $15 billion off BP's market value, reports the Guardian. The company's stock has been in freefall since the failure to stop the spill and Hayward's comments.

– The Justice Department's announcement that it's opening a criminal and civil investigation into the Gulf oil spill sent BP shares tumbling another 8% today. The company's market value has dived 36% since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded in April, notes the Financial Times. BP CEO Tony Hayward is in hot water, and the Times editorial board is calling for a "sea change" in the way the company cleans up the mess. "After the oil spill, we need a sea change," the editors write. "The president needs to show competence," they write. "Maybe BP had finally done something right and begun to contain the devastating oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, which is spewing at least 12,000 barrels of crude every day since 20 April into a vital commercial fishing area and bird habitat, creating what we officially started calling in late May the US's worst—ever environmental disaster."

– BP CEO Tony Hayward is on the outs with President Obama over the Gulf oil spill, and the president himself says Hayward would have been fired if he had been working for him. "If I had been Tony Hayward, I would have fired him immediately," Obama told Meet the Press. "I would have terminated his contract. I would have removed him from the company." BP shares fell 5% after Obama's comments.

– BP CEO Tony Hayward will head to Capitol Hill today for his first public comments on the Gulf oil spill, and he’ll likely be grilled about the company’s preparedness for the spill and why it took so long to start the project in the first place, the Wall Street Journal reports. Also on the agenda will be a hearing by the House Energy and Commerce Committee on the government’s oversight of the oil industry, as well as a hearing by the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee on the dangers posed by drilling rigs like BP’s Deepwater Horizon. Meanwhile, the Guardian reports that BP’s contingency plan for the spill was “riddled with errors” and was approved by the US government even though a dead scientist was listed as an expert in the document. Click here for more.

– President Obama will meet with BP CEO Tony Hayward tomorrow as the oil spill continues to spread along the Gulf Coast. Obama will also meet with Thad Allen, who is heading the government's response to the spill, and Coast Guard Commandant Thad Allen, who is in charge of the region's cleanup, the Washington Post reports. Meanwhile, the Guardian reports that the size of the spill has doubled to between 40,000 and 60,000 barrels, or about 220,000 gallons, based on video released this week.

– President Obama will try to reassure the nation tonight that he's got BP's back when it comes to the Gulf oil spill. In a prime-time speech at 9pm Eastern, the president will promise that the US will “hold BP accountable” and make the oil giant pay for the damage, the Washington Post reports. Obama will also announce that the federal government is ramping up its response to the spill, including the hiring of 1,000 Coast Guard workers and the installation of devices to capture the oil, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. BP CEO Tony Hayward will testify before a Senate panel today. Fitch has downgraded the company's credit rating to just two notches above junk status, reports the Guardian.

– BP CEO Tony Hayward's testimony before a House panel yesterday didn't exactly inspire confidence in the company's ability to contain the Gulf oil spill, reports the New York Times. Testimony that it could take two years to stop the spill and another four years to clean it up didn't sit well with residents of the Louisiana coast, who tell the Times that they're already seeing the effects of the spill on their land and water. "It's going to take a long time to clean up, it's going to take a long time to contain, it's going to take a long time to pay for, it's going to take a long time to remediate all the damage that has been done," says a resident of Grand Isle. "It's going to take a long time to clean up, it's going to take a long time to pay for, it's going to take a long time to remediate all the damage that has been done. It's going to be a mess."

– BP CEO Tony Hayward was replaced as the keynote speaker at an oil conference today by his deputy, Steve Westwell, after protesters interrupted his speech with a video of their protest. Greenpeace protesters interrupted a speech by Westwell at a major oil conference in London, urging the company to change its ways following the Deepwater Horizon disaster, the Guardian reports. BP's chief of staff was delivering the speech in place of Hayward, who had been scheduled to speak.

– Tony Hayward's days at the helm of BP are numbered, the company announced today, with American Bob Dudley taking charge of the company's response to the Gulf oil spill. Dudley, who has been with BP since 1979 and is currently the company's managing director, will lead the cleanup effort, along with a team of experts, the Guardian reports. Hayward, who has been with the company since 2001, will remain with the company as an adviser. The news comes as BP shares hit a 14-year low today.

– BP's chief executive is scheduled to meet with the head of the US Coast Guard today to discuss cleanup efforts in the wake of the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the Guardian reports. Coast Guard Adm. Igor Sechin will also meet with BP CEO Tony Hayward, BP's other top execs, and execs from other companies involved in the spill, including Transocean, Halliburton, and Cameron.

– BP's bill for the Gulf oil spill has passed the $3 billion mark, and the company has sent a letter to partners Anadarko and Japan's Mitsui Oil Exploration demanding that they hand over any assets they have tied up in the spill, the Guardian reports. Anadarko and Mitsui are BP's main suppliers of oil and gas in the Gulf, and the letter says that if they don't hand over any of their assets, they will be held liable for the spill's costs. BP says it will pay the full bill, which it expects to reach $4 billion by the end of the week, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico has hit a snag: The blowout preventer that was supposed to be attached to the well has failed to work properly, reports the New York Times. The company plans to replace it with a more powerful one over the weekend.

– BP successfully installed a new containment cap on its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico today, the Guardian reports. The device is expected to be in place as early as tomorrow to slow the oil flow. BP hopes the new cap will be able to capture most of the oil, but it will take a few days to test it.

– A  remotely operated vehicle has captured video of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill—the first time such a device has been used in such a large-scale operation, the Guardian reports. The remotely operated vehicle, orROV, is a small boat that can travel up to 3 miles on water and is equipped with a video camera. The footage shows the "blowout well" and other damage caused by the spill, including blowout preventers that are not working as well as they should. BP says the ROV will be used until it can be repaired or replaced. The last time such a device was used in such a large-scale operation was in the aftermath of the Lehman Brothers collapse in 2008.

– Looks like BP's new containment cap is working—at least for now. The company fixed a leak in the new containment system and is preparing to start pressure tests on the cap, the Guardian reports. If all goes according to plan, the cap will be able to capture most of the oil, a process that will take at least a day. But it will be at least a week before engineers know whether it works, and if it does, they'll have to decide what to do next. The best-case scenario is that the cap will be able to capture all of the oil, a process that will take at least a day. If it doesn't, BP will have to open the well again to install another containment system.

– Thad Allen, the Coast Guard's top official in the Gulf of Mexico, said today that seepage at the site of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill is unlikely to be linked to the plugged well. "We don't know how much is out there," Allen said at a news conference, according to the Guardian. "We don't know what's leaking. We don't know how much is on the surface of the water. We don't know whether it's coming from the wellhead or from the annulus of the wellhead." The National Hurricane Center has issued a hurricane watch for the Gulf.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico appears to have hit a dead end. The company said it had managed to stop at least some of the oil from flowing, but it was unable to permanently plug the well in 5,000 feet of water, reports the New York Times. The news comes as the company admitted that some of the images posted on its website—including one of the command center—had been doctored, notes the Guardian.

– The chief technician for TransOcean, the owner of the oil rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico last month, has revealed that safety systems on the rig were turned off to help workers sleep, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. The revelation comes during a House Energy and Commerce Committee hearing on TransOcean's preparedness for the Deepwater Horizon spill. TransOcean says the alarm systems were turned off to help workers sleep.

– Tony Hayward is out as CEO of BP after a scandal-plagued tenure marked by gaffes like "I’d like my life back" and "We can’t stop the oil flowing." BP announced Hayward’s resignation today and said a new CEO would be named within days, the Wall Street Journal reports. “I am confident that a new generation of management will lead BP through this difficult period,” Hayward said in a letter to employees. “I am confident that the new management team will lead BP through this difficult period with complete focus.” Hayward will receive a one-time payout of about $500,000 and a pension of about half a million pounds, the Telegraph reports.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spill has been foiled by a live video that purports to show huge amounts of oil pouring into the Gulf of Mexico. The video, posted on the company's website, is at least five minutes long and purports to show "significant quantities" of oil coming from the gushing well, the Guardian reports. It's not clear whether the video is genuine, but it's drawing lots of attention because it's being called "shocking" by some and "shocking" by others. Click here for more on the spill.

– Looks like BP's "static kill" operation is working—at least according to the White House, which says 75% of the oil has been captured, burned, or broken down. The next step will be to pump mud into the well to seal it permanently, a process that could take up to 3 days, the Wall Street Journal reports. The last thing BP wants is to have to deal with a huge environmental disaster in the wake of the failed "top kill" operation, so the company is hoping President Obama will sign off on the plan as soon as possible, notes the Guardian.

– The Deepwater Horizon oil spill has taken a heavy toll on wildlife in the US, especially on endangered brown pelicans. The birds have been injured or killed at a rate not seen since the Gulf oil spill in 1979, according to the US Geological Survey. The number of injured or killed brown pelicans is the highest it has been since the spill began, the Guardian reports. Brown pelicans are a critically endangered species that can only be found in the US.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the Gulf oil spill has failed, and it will take at least a day to know for sure whether it worked, the Wall Street Journal reports. The company had hoped to seal the well with mud, but that will take at least 24 hours, and it will take at least a day to know for sure whether it worked. The news comes as the Obama administration revealed that it granted BP exemptions to drill the well based on decades-old data, the Guardian reports.

– The BP oil spill is taking a heavy toll on the insurance industry, with several companies reporting big drops in first-half profits. Hiscox, for example, said it had a 44-cent drop in first-half profits, while Amlin said it had a 70-cent drop in profits, the Telegraph reports. "Clearly, the events in Deepwater Horizon have had a significant impact on our business," said Hiscox's CEO. "However, we remain confident in our ability to weather these storms and return to profitability in the second half of the year."
– BP frozen out of Arctic oil drilling race British energy giant BP forced to abandon hopes of Greenland exploration owing to tarnished reputation from Gulf oil spill Wednesday 25 August 2010

– BP's chief executive says the oil company is working hard to contain the damage from the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, but it will take years to clean up the mess. "I think it's going to take us a long time," Tony Hayward told the British parliament yesterday. "It's going to take us a long time to plug the well. It's going to take us a long time to stop the flow of oil. It's going to take us a long time to pay for the damage that's been done to the environment, to the people who work on the well, to the businesses that depend on the oil and the oil industry as a whole." Hayward said the company has spent $2 billion so far on cleanup efforts, but that figure is expected to rise. "It's going to take a long time to stop the flow of oil," he said. "It's not going to be an easy task. It's not going to be an easy task to stop the flow of oil. It's going to take a long time to contain the leak. It's going to take a long time to stop the flow of oil."

– BP's long-awaited report on the Gulf oil spill is out, and it blames everything from the design of the well to the actions of the crew working on the rig for the disaster, reports the Wall Street Journal. The report generally blames Transocean, owner of the rig, and Halliburton, owner of the blowout preventer, but BP itself is taking much of the blame for its own failures, including the fact that it didn't have adequate control over the blowout preventer, notes the Guardian. Transocean and Halliburton are both suing BP, and the Justice Department is investigating the cause of the accident.

– BP's incoming CEO says the oil giant will probably end up paying out less than it has committed to paying out in compensation for the Gulf oil spill. Bob Dudley, who will take over as CEO in October, told the City of London that claims from spill victims will probably fall below the $20 billion the company has committed to paying out, the Guardian reports. "It's going to take a while to pay all the claims," Dudley said. "But I'm confident we're going to get it right." BP has set aside $30 billion for Gulf oil spill compensation.

– For the first time in 11 years, BP is on the list of the world's 100 best brands, reports the Guardian. The oil giant's brand value has been decimated by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, according to a leading marketing consultancy, which blames the "disastrous financial, political, and PR fallout." Apple is now the world's No. 1 brand, while BP is at the bottom of the list. BP's brand value has been decimated by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, according to a leading marketing consultancy. The disastrous financial, political, and PR fallout from the Deepwater Horizon spill has stripped billions of dollars from the value of the BP brand, according to a leading marketing consultancy, which has dumped the oil giant from its index of the world's best brands for the first time in 11 years. The disastrous financial, political, and PR fallout from the Deepwater Horizon spill has stripped billions of dollars from the value of the BP brand, according to a leading marketing consultancy, which has dumped the oil giant from its index of the world's best brands for the first time in 11 years.

– It's safe to say that the worst oil spill in US history is over. BP successfully plugged its ruptured well in the Gulf of Mexico today, five months after the first explosion on the Deepwater Horizon rig, the Wall Street Journal reports. Analysts say that even if it takes a few days to seal the well, it will be much easier to clean up the mess than to deal with the long-term consequences. BP shares rose sharply after the news broke, the Guardian reports. The company has set up a $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the spill.

– An investigative report commissioned by President Obama has revealed that the White House office of management and budget blocked scientists seeking permission to show worst-case scenario models two weeks after the explosion of the BP oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico. The report states that the White House's Office of Management and Budget didn't approve the models because they were based on an overly optimistic estimate of the amount of oil that could be spilled, reports the New York Times.

– BP CEO Bob Dudley said today that the oil giant will not be quitting the US after the Deepwater Horizon disaster, the Guardian reports. “We will not be quitting America,” he told the Confederation of British Industry in London. “We will rebuild the trust of the American people.” Dudley said BP is working on solutions to the Gulf oil spill, but admitted that the company had “some very tough decisions” to make. “We’re not going to walk away from America,” he said. “We’re going to be here for a long time.”

– The Justice Department is investigating whether BP and Halliburton knew about problems with the cement used in the well that ruptured in the Gulf of Mexico earlier this year, killing 11 and causing the biggest oil spill in US history. Investigators say the cement used on the well did not meet industry standards, the Guardian reports. BP and Halliburton knew of problems with the cement mixture three out of four tests carried out before the explosion, according to investigators. Investigators say the cement used on the well did not meet industry standards.

– BP raised its estimate of the cost of the Deepwater Horizon oil disaster to nearly 40 billion dollars today, the Wall Street Journal reports. The new figure, up from a previous estimate of around 27 billion dollars, includes cleanup costs, the cost of BP's efforts to contain the oil, and the cost of damage to the ocean floor, which is expected to take years to clean up. BP also said it will set up a $20 billion fund to help victims of the disaster, the New York Times reports.

– Tony Hayward, BP's infamous CEO before his ouster in the wake of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, is making headlines again, this time for telling a BBC documentary that it's easier to hate an individual than a company. In BP: The Man Who Killed, Hayward says it's easier to hate an individual than a company, and he's referring to the mistakes made by BP, Halliburton, and Transocean before and during the disaster. "It's easier to hate an individual than it is to hate a company," he says, according to the Guardian.

– An Alaska judge has ordered BP to pay a $1 million fine for its role in a 2006 oil spill—the largest environmental fine in state history, the Anchorage Daily News reports. The company was already on probation for causing the spill when it failed to respond to warnings about burst pipelines, according to court documents. The judge also ordered BP to pay $5 million in cleanup costs. The spill released 40,000 gallons of oil into the environment.

– BP's $20 billion oil-spill compensation fund will pay out just $2.3 billion to victims of the Gulf oil spill, administrator Ken Feinberg announced today. That's less than half of the total amount needed to cover emergency claims, and significantly less than the $60 billion President Obama had hoped the fund would be able to pay, the Wall Street Journal reports. Feinberg says he expects to pay out $6 billion to spill victims by the end of September. Obama had promised to pay out $20 billion in the wake of the spill.

– The White House is set to release its report on the BP oil spill today, and it's expected to blame the company for many of the mistakes that caused the disaster. The report will include BP's internal records as well as those of the Coast Guard and the US government, reports the Wall Street Journal. Among other things, it's expected to call out BP's handling of the disaster, including its slow response. The report also is expected to criticize BP's efforts to contain the spill, notes the New York Times.

– The Justice Department has filed a lawsuit against BP and other companies involved in the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, alleging that they violated safety regulations and caused the worst oil spill in US history, the New York Times reports. The lawsuit, which seeks billions of dollars in damages, was filed in a New Orleans court and was announced by Attorney General Eric Holder at a press conference today. The Justice Department is also suing Transocean, Halliburton, and Cameron, according to the Guardian. Transocean and Cameron are among the companies named in the lawsuit.

– A British parliamentary report on the Gulf oil spill is out today, and it's not good news for BP. The report concludes that the US oil spill was caused by a "systemic" problem, not BP's actions, and calls for an independent inquiry into the matter, the Telegraph reports. The report also criticizes the US government for its slow response to the spill, and says BP should be held accountable for the damage it caused. "It is clear that the US government could have done more to prevent the spill, but it has failed to do so," the chair of the House of Commons Energy and Constitutional Affairs Committee tells the Guardian.

– BP has agreed to waive the legal cap on its liability for the Gulf oil spill, a move that will allow it to pay far less in clean-up costs than it would have if it had kept fighting the spill all the way to the Supreme Court, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. BP said in a court filing yesterday that it had decided to waive the statutory limitation on liability under the Oil Pollution Act, which would have allowed it to pay just 75 million dollars plus clean-up costs. "BP has chosen to waive the statutory limitation on liability under OPA," the company said in the court filing. The move is a sign of BP's seriousness in cleaning up the mess, the Times-Picayune notes.

– BP's chief executive Tony Hayward says he is "incredibly proud" of the company's progress on the Gulf oil spill. In an interview with CNN's Don Lemon, Hayward said he is "comfortable" with BP's latest plan to lower a relief well into the gushing pipe. "We're going to make it work," he said. "We're not going to stop all the way to the surface, we're going to just lower the pipe one at a time. It's going to be a relief well, and then we'll know whether we can plug it from the bottom."

– The US government’s latest estimate of the amount of oil flowing into the Gulf of Mexico is about 5,000 barrels a day—or about two-and-a-half times the size of the largest spill in US history, writes Justin Gillis at the Atlantic. The figure is “a massive underestimate, and the stated reason for not getting a better figure is weak indeed,” he writes. A spokesman for the federal government, which estimates the flow rate at 5,000 barrels a day, says the figure will not affect either the direction or scale of our response, which is the largest in history.

– President Obama says the White House will set up a commission to investigate the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. In his weekly radio and Internet address, Obama also said offshore oil drilling could only go forward if there were assurances that such accidents would not happen again, reports the Los Angeles Times. “This is a breakdown of responsibility on the part of BP,” he said. “The American people deserve to know exactly what happened and who is responsible for it.”

– The feds are going to hit BP with big fines over the Gulf oil spill, a top official tells the Times-Picayune. “We are going to do everything in our power to ensure that the oil company is held accountable,” said Thad Allen, the federal official in charge of the cleanup. BP insists it's doing everything it can to contain the oil, but the feds aren't buying it. “There is no magic solution,” said President Obama in his first public comments on the spill. “There is no magic fix.” Click here for more.

– The Coast Guard has told BP to fire when ready with its so-called "top kill" plan. The idea is to pump mud into the gushing well to plug it, but the Coast Guard wants BP to fire when it's safe to do so, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. It's not clear whether the plan will work, but the Coast Guard wants BP to fire when it's safe to do so. The Times-Picayune has more on the timeline here.

– The Coast Guard has told BP to fire if it can't stop the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. – Director James Cameron has offered to help clean up the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, but BP turned him down, he tells the BBC. Cameron, who says he has seen first-hand the damage the spill is doing to the region, offered to send a team to the Gulf to help clean up the mess, but BP turned him down, he said. The director, who says he has never met BP CEO Tony Hayward, also offered to send a team of his own to help clean up the spill. Click here for more on Cameron's offer.

– BP managed to capture more of the oil pouring into the Gulf of Mexico in 24 hours, but President Obama says he wants to know who's really at fault. "I want to know who's responsible for this spill," he said at the White House yesterday, according to the Washington Post. "I want to know who's responsible for this money that's going to be spent on this cleanup operation." Obama's comments come as the Coast Guard warned that the spill could take years to clean up, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. BP said it had captured 10,500 barrels of oil in 24 hours, up from 439,950 gallons in 24 hours, and that a second containment system should enable it to soon control the vast majority of oil spewing from the leak about 1 mile below the water's surface.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the Gulf oil spill didn't work as well as hoped, and the company will have to pony up much more money for cleanup if it wants to avoid a lawsuit, a federal judge ruled today. The judge said that the US government's approach of pumping mud into the gushing well to plug it didn't work, reports the New York Times. "The blowout preventer is not working as well as we would like it to," he said. "We will be paying for the cleanup costs for a long time to come." BP will have to pony up an average of $75,000 a day for the next three months to help clean up the spill, the judge said, adding that the amount the company will have to pay is "in the tens of millions of dollars." The judge's ruling came as the Obama administration promised to step up efforts to contain the oil.

– Florida Attorney General Bill McCollum is demanding that BP deposit $2.5 billion into an escrow account to cover potential losses from the Gulf oil spill, the Wall Street Journal reports. State officials say they are feeling the effects, both environmentally and financially, and that they need much more than what BP is offering to recover lost wages and taxes. McCollum sent a letter to BP yesterday requesting that the company deposit $2.5 billion into an escrow account to cover potential losses. – BP has agreed to set up a $20 billion fund to pay for the Gulf oil spill, and it will cut its dividend for the first time since 1997, the Financial Times reports. The company will also set up a fund to pay spill-related claims and compensate fishermen and businesses. BP CEO Tony Hayward, who was heavily criticized for his response to the spill, will not be part of the fund, the company said in a statement.

– BP's latest estimate of the amount of oil spilling into the Gulf of Mexico is about 100,000 barrels a day, or about two-and-a-half times the amount the US Geological Survey estimated last week, the Washington Post reports. The document was released yesterday by a senior Democrat on the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The estimate is based on 5,000 barrels of oil a day being spilled, which is about two-and-a-half times the amount the US Geological Survey estimated last week. BP said in a statement that it is working to contain the oil.

– One of New Orleans’ most prominent chefs has filed a lawsuit against BP, claiming the oil spill is damaging the city’s seafood industry. The suit, which names BP, Transocean, Halliburton, and Cameron, seeks damages for restaurants that have lost normal seafood supplies as a result of the spill, reports the Times-Picayune. BP spent 300 million dollars on the Gulf oil spill response in the past three days, its first time ever hitting the $100 million/day spend rate, according to Reuters.

– BP's current estimate of how much oil it can skim from the Gulf of Mexico is way off the mark, according to a new report in Nature. A March report from BP said it could remove 491,721 barrels of oil a day, but the Minerals Management Service says that's just 200,000 barrels a day. BP only got the permits to start drilling at the Deepwater Horizon site in the first place because the Minerals Management Service believed their statement that they could recover 197 percent of the daily discharge from an uncontrolled blowout of 250,000 barrels per day, writes Kimberly Kindy at Boing Boing.

– The blowout preventer that failed to stop the Deepwater Horizon oil spill had a dead battery, leaks in its hydraulic system, a “useless” test version of a key component, and a cutting tool that was not strong enough to cut through steel joints in the well pipe, according to a House investigation. Rep. Bart Stupak, chair of the House panel investigating the spill, called the blowout preventer “a devastating review of the blowout preventer, which BP said was supposed to be ‘ fail—safe,’” reports the Los Angeles Times. BP executive Lamar McKay, who will testify before the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee today, said the blowout preventer’s battery had died. “It’s going to take a long time to plug this well,” he said. Allen will continue to serve as President Obama's point man on the Gulf Coast oil spill after he retires this month, the administration said yesterday. – Interior Secretary Ken Salazar says he's "angry and frustrated" that BP hasn't been able to plug its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico. Salazar, who's scheduled to meet with President Obama at the White House today, said yesterday that the administration is "absolutely determined to get to the bottom of what's happening" and that he's "frustrated" that BP hasn't been able to seal the well, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. BP CEO Tony Hayward has said that it could take a week to get to the bottom of the problem.

– The Coast Guard has told BP to fire when ready with its so-called "top kill" plan. The idea is to pump mud into the gushing well to plug it, a practice that has worked on land but never been tried at the ocean's surface. The Coast Guard has told BP to fire if it doesn't work, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. If it doesn't, BP will have to wait at least a day for the results of the live video operation, which is expected to last at least 24 hours. Click here for more on the plan.

– BP's latest attempt to plug its oil well in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work out so well, and the company will now try again with a so-called "top kill." The idea is to pump mud into the well to plug it, but it's not clear whether that will work, notes the Washington Post. The live video feed of BP's latest attempt is live, but it's not clear whether it works. Click here for a live blog of the latest news on the spill.

– The White House ordered BP to pay for five more large sections of Louisiana barrier island sand berms today as efforts to contain the Deepwater Horizon oil spill hit more obstacles and the slick approached Florida. The White House ordered BP to pay for construction of five more large sections of Louisiana barrier island sand berms today as efforts to contain the gushing Deepwater Horizon oil spill hit more obstacles and the slick approached Florida, reports the Los Angeles Times. The spill has already closed oyster beds, shut down shrimpers, canceled fishing tournaments, and panicked beach hoteliers from New Orleans to Key West.

– As the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico spreads, the environmental toll is only expected to grow, and it could take decades to clean up, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. The damage to the ocean's ecology is already visible, with blobs of oil washing up on the beaches of Louisiana and Mexico, and scientists say the damage could be even worse than that. “It’s going to take a long time to clean up,” says a marine ecologist. “It’s going to be very, very ugly.” Click here for more on the environmental toll.

– BP CEO Tony Hayward arrived at the White House today for a scheduled 2pm meeting with President Obama and other administration officials to discuss the growing oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The meeting comes as the administration rejected EU offers of state-of-the-art oil-skimming equipment and Canada's offer of nearly 10,000 feet of absorbent boom, the Washington Post reports. In a letter released yesterday, House Democrats accused BP of taking " shortcuts" in the drilling of the well that is now spewing oil into the Gulf. "It is an ecological disaster," writes Eugene Robinson in the Post. "Yes, the BP oil spill is Obama's Katrina."

– When BP CEO Tony Hayward appeared before a House panel today to take his lumps over the Gulf oil spill, he managed only a single word of apology, notes Aaron Blake and Paul Kane of the Washington Post. "I am deeply sorry," he said. "It is not easy to divvy up $ 20 billion. Perhaps no one in America knows this better than Kenneth Feinberg." In his opening remarks, Rep. Joe Barton, a Texas Republican, tried to walk that back, notes the Hill, saying, "I am not going to apologize for the actions of BP."

– BP installed a new, deeper cap on its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico today, but the plan has been delayed until at least tomorrow, reports the Washington Post. The company had promised to conduct a test today to see if the cap worked, and if so, whether it could stop the oil flow permanently. The development comes as the Interior Department rolled out a new moratorium on deep-water drilling, a move designed to get around an injunction issued by a New Orleans federal judge.

– SpongeBob SquarePants and his pals in Bikini Bottom have a message for the BP contractors, cleanup crews, and news media descending on Grand Isle, La., where oil from the Deepwater Horizon oil spill is washing up almost daily. John Aravosis of Americablog.com pointed out alterations, including jagged white edges around the silhouettes of the subjects. Click here for more.

– The death toll from yesterday's devastating earthquake in Haiti could be in the tens of thousands, according to Haitian officials who have been unable to reach the capital city of Port-au-Prince. The country's president-elect, Michel Martelly, says the toll could be in the tens of thousands, the AP reports. President Obama has called in the US military to help with relief efforts, and Bill Clinton is en route to the country, the BBC reports. Meanwhile, aid is starting to pour in from around the world.

– The death toll from the Haiti earthquake now stands at 50,000, according to Haitian officials, but that doesn't mean the situation is easy. Relief workers are struggling to get food, water, and medical supplies to survivors, and violence is spreading. "There are tens of thousands of children that have been orphaned by the earthquake," a spokesman for an international aid agency tells the BBC. "It's going to be a very long process to reunite them with their families." Meanwhile, Bill Clinton visited Port-au-Prince, where he met with Prime Minister Jean-Max Bellerive and pledged US aid.

– Relief workers in Haiti are still struggling to get food, water, and medical supplies to survivors—and the country's prime minister says the death toll from the devastating earthquake could be in the tens of thousands. Jean-Max Bellerive told the AP that the country's president and members of his family were among the dead in the capital of Port-au-Prince. "There are tens of thousands of people who have been killed in Port-au-Prince," Bellerive said. "There are a lot of people who have been saved, but there are a lot of people who are still buried in the rubble." He said the government was working to "get the bodies out of the city and get them to the villages." In other developments: Haiti is moving earthquake survivors out of the capital and into safer camps outside Port-au-Prince, the Guardian reports. The interior minister said 100,000 people would initially be sent to 10 settlements near the suburb of Croix Des Bouquets, where at least 500,000 people are living in bad conditions. Simon Cowell is organizing a charity single to raise funds for the Haiti earthquake appeal, the BBC reports. He said he had a request to record a single from Prime Minister Gordon Brown and the Sun.
